REVIEW_TITLE: Great place for a day and night visit
REVIEW_BODY: Start with a walk in the gardens in the morning, those with kids can visit the Far East Organization's Children's garden, where you can find a playground and water park (hidden gem!) and head to the air-conditioned Flower Dome/ Cloud Forest later in the afternoon when it gets hot. A good place for lunch will be Pollen or the Peach Garden Noodle House, or just good ol' Macdonalds for those with kids! For the later part of the evening, head to Satay by the Bay for delicious skewered meats or dine at Majestic Bay Seafood restaurant. When it gets dark, head to the Supertree Grove and walk atop on the OCBC Skyway (not for those with height phobia though!)
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
The Cloud Forest simulates the mountainous regions and allows one to experience what it feels like high in the mountains as well as see the kind of flora and fauna that is indigenous to that area._x000D_
_x000D_
The larger of the two domes in Gardens by the Bay, the climate controlled Cloud Forest boasts the tallest indoor waterfall that greets you at the entrance._x000D_
_x000D_
Start your exploration in the Cloud Forest by taking the lift up and then walk down the spiraling walkways to admire the types of plants that can be found at various altitudes on a mountain._x000D_

REVIEW_BODY:
The views at the top of the observation deck are simply stunning, especially at night. However, it does cost a rather expensive 23 Singapore Dollars to get to the top for an attraction you could easily complete in just 15 minutes. Therefore, if you do decide to go I'd advise milking the views for all they are worth and maybe bring a small picnic to enjoy while you take in the breathtaking Singapore city scenery._x000D_
_x000D_
The observation deck is open 9.30am to 10pm from Mondays to Thursdays and 9.30am to 11pm from Fridays to Sundays. I would recommend purchasing a ticket and heading up to the observation deck just before the Wonder Full showtimes, which is Southeast Asia's largest light and water show. I saw the one at 8pm (there's another one at 9.30pm and an additional 11pm one from Fridays to Saturdays) and was impressed by the colourful water sprouts and laser effects._x000D_
_x000D_
I managed to get some awesome looking night scenery photos of the Singapore Flyer, Gardens By The Bay and of the city skyline so definitely remember to bring your camera with you for some fantastic photo opportunities! :)
ADDRESS: 10 Bayfront Avenue | Level 57, Marina Bay Sands Hotel, Singapore 018956, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Surely one of Singapore's top 3 attraction
REVIEW_BODY: The first thing that hits you when you reach this place is that there is hardly any crowd. This is probably because very compartment of the flyer can easily take in 20 individuals and the whole trip can be over in less than 40 minutes which is more than enough. This means the visit can be experienced in relative peace. Almost all areas of Singapore city can be seen from this flyer. My recommendation is to take the flyer first then make a note of all the places seen from here and then chart out your visits to these places as you have your orientation right and can plan accordingly. There is a nice restaurant right below the flyover run by two elderly gentlemen and that food was pretty awesome.

REVIEW_BODY:
Absolutely fascinating museum, which bucks the usual trend of separating Asian artefacts one from another( this is the Korean section, this the Indian section, this the Malayan, this the Chinese etc etc ). Instead it shows how via trade in particular , the various religions and communities have developed differently but folowing remarkably similar patterns._x000D_
Brilliantly curated, with intelligent information provided for practically every exhibit, you emerge with a much clearer view about how much apparently different societies have in common, rather than how antipathetic their apparent divergences might have made them._x000D_
_x000D_
Such a cosmopolitan approach exemplifies the best of what Singapore stands for. So it is utterly fitting that this unique museum should belong here. Not to be missed,. And the entrance fee is so reasonable that it permits multiple trips.
ADDRESS: 1 Empress Place Empress Place Building, Singapore 179555, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: A taste of India in Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: My husband and I spent the best part of a day wondering the streets of this area. It really felt like we were in India, the food the smells, the architecture. We wondered through Mustafa and couldn't believe the unusual things we picked up. I even bought a great saucepan at a fantastic price. You can pick up anything and everything here, from toiletries to gardening equipment. It is massive and usually packed with people grabbing their bargains. The food in little India is authentic and if you are hankering for a spicy delight, this is the place to be. The Indian sweets are also authentic and available throughout the place. We loved the market type stalls but we're disappointed with the prices and the stall holders weren't as flexible with haggling as they are in India. I guess they are used to tourists paying top dollar here.

Right from the structures that add to the 360 view of the Marina Bay sands in the back drop, it is a paradise for people who loves botany, Garden by the Bay has 2 domes, Flower Dome and Rain-forest Cloud Dome (unfortunately this was closed on that day when we arrived). This is certainly a must visit place.

REVIEW_BODY: We visited the Gardens on our first morning in Singapore. As we weren't acclimatised to the humidity, we elected to visit the domes only. A mostly air-conditioned walk from Bayfront MRT took us to the Gardens trolley shuttle stop. We thought it was worth the $3 for unlimited rides for the day to/from the Domes. It was great to be able to view the extensive domes gardens in air-conditioned comfort. The first impression of each dome is WOW! They far exceeded our expectations. Loved the diverse collection of plants in the flower dome. Loved the design of the cloud forest and its downhill skywalk. Well worth visiting.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

It's the most impressive site in the area.

REVIEW_BODY: Living in Singapore can sometimes seem like living in a giant construction site: roads torn up, parking areas devoured by mechanical beasts, traffic diverted - great disruption. All part of the price of establishing a world-class subway system. The Botanic Gardens however, are a huge green oasis, bequeathed to us by generations for foresightful individuals and governments. Strolling, jogging, walking the dog, or however, the Gardens are refreshingly peaceful clean and green, a place to relax, reflect, and admire some of the wonders of nature. Watch the fish at Swan Lake, watch or participate in the morning Tai Chi and exercise sessions. Join a fitness boot camp. Enjoy a drink or meal at one of the several cafes and restaurants. Marvel at one of the world's great orchid collections. Or just wander, people watching. If you live in Singapore, you have no need of this advice, but if you are visiting don't miss it! Dress casually, and lightly, with a hat if you will. You won't regret it.
ADDRESS: 1 Cluny Road, Singapore 259 569, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Wow! An amazing place. The gardens are a mixture of different themed gardens all of them set out well and full of interesting art or displays. We spent several hours walking around the several acres. You can pay for a shuttle but if you can it is much better to walk and enjoy the park. The artwork is outstanding all over. The children's area has a wonderful water play area with good facilities to shower afterwards. The ultra modern tree sculptures are fabulous especially during the free nightly light show. You can pay a few dollars to enjoy the walkway between the trees, not really worth it but pleasant to do for the views._x000D_
The domes cost but are amazing, in my opinion a must-do. They are both excellent and full of some of the best modern sculptures I have ever seen. They were a highlight of our visit to Singapore and not to be missed. Allow a few hours and they will stamp your arm so you can return the same evening and enjoy a different experience while the light show is on.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Great day at Singapore Zoo with my family! my 6-yr-old son love it so much!!!
REVIEW_BODY: I couldn't believe I've waited this long before finally paying Singapore Zoo a visit! There were many wild animals. The rain-forest track was really good since you could get really close to the wild animals with bats darting above your head at some point! It's a pity that the outback (Australia zone) was closed for maintenance. It's far cleaner than Safari World, Thailand. You learnt a lot of new things about wildlife during a one day trip. Animal information was provided in a fun way that make even my 6 year old son wanna stop and read. My son was really happy in there and the best part is that we could continue the trip and made our son feel even happier by going the River Safari right after we finished the tour in Singapore Zoo.

REVIEW_TITLE: Awesome day for young and old!
REVIEW_BODY:
We visited the Singapore Zoo last week and had an amazing day! The animals all looked very well cared for and it was nice to see such open spaces without small enclosures._x000D_

REVIEW_BODY:
If touring Singapore is only about parties, rooftop vistas, and the best Singapore Sling, then PLEASE skip this temple._x000D_
_x000D_
This place is for non-Buddhists/Hindus who have a curiosity about other cultures, appreciation of what the Buddha and his followers have brought to the world, or genuinely desire some calm tranquility along their journey, OR for Buddhists/Hindus/followers of Dharmic philosophy that have a devotional attachment to the connection that this Temple offers._x000D_
_x000D_
It is amazing to think we have access to a part of the Buddhaâ€™s mortal body from 2,500 years ago, and that the Temple has been created so thoughtfully and allows for visitors to interact so deeply with everything there is truly open and generous._x000D_
_x000D_
It will always feature on my visits to Singapore.

REVIEW_TITLE: To take a cable car for Sentosa

REVIEW_TITLE: Stunning zoo, beautiful setting, a wonderful day out
REVIEW_BODY: Singapore zoo houses a diverse collection of animals housed in spacious, naturalistic, humane conditions. A joy to see so many free ranging (relatively) primates particularly orang utans. My favourite exhibit is the Hydramas Baboon enclosure for its scale, authentic environment and the fascinating interplay between the many different groups of baboons of all ages. I could sit and watch them all day. Do not miss this if you visit...it makes for a relatively expensive family day out but one which enriches your life and truly offers good value, an increasing rarity in Singapore sadly.

REVIEW_BODY:
A Casualty of War: There was a time, not that very long ago, when whatâ€™s now Orchard Road was pristine jungle, and salt-water crocs slithered up the riverbank where Clarke Quay now stands. But as jungles go in Singapore, most of them have packed and gone. Bukit Timah is the last real hilltop jungle left, but itâ€™s no match for the ancient jungles you can still find in Borneo, New Guinea, and other undisturbed places. Less than 80 years ago, Bukit Timah itself was very disturbed: by tanks, artillery barrages, dive bombers and mortars. In little more than 12 hoursâ€”from dusk on 10 February 1942 to dawn the next morning, the Battle of Bukit Timah laid waste to what had been the most pristine bit of highland jungle Singapore had. By 0800 on 11 February, Bukit Timahâ€™s ecosystem was shell-shocked and critically wounded. And then, for another three decades, the bukit was subjected to additional stresses, such as unrestricted vehicle traffic._x000D_
_x000D_
Recovery: Not all the old trees were destroyed, and some saplings that sprang up over the next decades are now mature. But donâ€™t expect a pristine, climax tropical rain-forest. In Sumatra, weâ€™ve been through jungle with a canopy so dense that the floor was sunless and gloomy at high noon on a cloudless day. The canopy is still patchy at Bukit Timah (see Canopy Gaps photo); perhaps in another 20 or 50 years.... Still, Bukit Timahâ€™s jungle is seven years older than the first time I saw it, and looks a bit denser, perhaps._x000D_
_x000D_
Convenience: On the other hand, this is the best upland jungle that Singaporeâ€™s got, and the fact that Singaporeâ€™s got it, rather than Sarawak or Sumatra, means that itâ€™s considerably more accessible. Itâ€™s at your doorstep (literally so, if you live in an apartment at the bottom of the bukit). Instead of spending three days reaching remote jungles up-country from Kuching or Medan, you can start hiking up Bukit Timah at high noon and be back down again by tea-time._x000D_
_x000D_
Ease of Ascent: Bukit Timah, as a pedestrian stroll, is much improved since seven years ago, when hikers climbed up (and even more carefully down) a steep and deeply-rutted dirt trail that was treacherous when dry and homicidal when wet. Nowadays theyâ€™ve got a well-engineered hiking path taking you up the bukit, and proper stairs with hand-ropes no less, all far safer than the former accommodations. The summit of Bukit Timah is the highest point in the entire country, but at 164 meters (538 ft), this trek is still easier than a steep climb up to the nightâ€™s camp-ground in the Alps of Switzerland, the Andes of Peru, or the auberges of Paris when their lift is out of order as usual. (However, Iâ€™ll qualify that with some cautions at the end of my review.)_x000D_
_x000D_
Animals: The tigers of Bukit Timuh, a terror in the mid-1800s, have long since been eradicated, but pythons, pangolins and flying colugos are still up on the bukit, somewhere, as are a variety of birds such as barbets and bulbuls. In my visits to Bukit Timah, Iâ€™ve heard birds far more often than Iâ€™ve spotted them, and never encountered most of the animal species that are up there. Except macaques. On a few rare occasions, Iâ€™ve found macaques; but normally they always find me first. The macaques have turned brazen due to humans feeding them. Theyâ€™re not domesticated, but their independent jungle self-sufficiency appears to be waning, while their hooliganism is waxing. I suspect the timid and skittish ones are youngsters still learning the ropes. If your primary goal is to see lots of Southeast Asian jungle animals, head to Singapore Zoo; their cousins are rather shy and retiring up on the bukit._x000D_
_x000D_
The Song of the Jungle: With luck, within a few minutes walk from the Visitor Centre, youâ€™ll be surrounded by the primordial music of the jungleâ€”the song of the cicadas. The reason youâ€™ll need luck is that if any group of hikers is nearbyâ€”laughing, joking, and talking in loud voices--theyâ€™ll spook the cicadas (the breaking of a single
ADDRESS: 177 Hindhede Drive Bukit Timah Vhf Station, Singapore 589333, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
My husband and I had 12 hours to kill in Singapore! We took the MRT to Marina Bay Sands to experience the skylark and lunch. We started with a qwik beer in the lobby bar ( as we were a little early for lunch).. We took the option of a meal for lunch at the Asian fusion restaurant Ce La Vi on the 57th floor a truly spectacular view of Singapore skyline and a lunch that was exceptional yet very expensive. A Pinot noir from New Zealand will set you back about $150AUD and the set menu for $68 was very reasonable. We had king fish for starters, wagyu for mains and the dessert was a chocolate concoction to die for! It did rain a little but that did not have any impact on the view, in fact I think the fact that they closed the bar that was outside the restaurant only enhanced the view._x000D_
We then took the MRT to little India for another sensory sensation! If you follow me, you will see where we went next!
ADDRESS: 10 Bayfront Avenue | Level 57, Marina Bay Sands Hotel, Singapore 018956, Singapore

This is a huge area which is free to wander round,however if you want to access the domes (Flower Dome and Forest) or the Skyway ,you have to pay. They are well worth it as there are endless photo opportunities and the waterfall is amazing. There are numerous cafes and reastaurants which serve a variety of food and drink. You also get good views of the adjacent boat shaped hotel(The Marina Bay Sands), which rises high into the sky offering panoramic views(at a cost!) and a garden which is accessible to hotel guests only. REVIEW_BODY: Loved!!! the free tour on a Saturday where we got to see all the orchids We were toured around by a special guide who offered all kinds of wonderful information and answered all of our questions with a smile. We really learned a lot about orchids, not only their beauty, but their ability to express sentiment and to be a part of the culture here in Singapore. Can't wait to return on another day for another tour of the rainforest or similar area. The botanic gardens here are likely some of the most spectacular ever. We feel so blessed to have been able to visit. You will enjoy your trip here, finding out there are tens of thousands of orchids in the world, and thousands of different palm trees as well. This is an eye-opening experience, and quite a wonderful way to get to know the beauty and the grandeur of nature. Bring bottled water, your camera, a sun hat, maybe a hand fan, umbrella, and wear comfy walking shoes. Consider having lunch at the gardens afterward.
ADDRESS: 1 Cluny Road, Singapore 259 569, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: The big question I had prior to visiting was it worth visiting Gardens By The Bay and not pay to enter one of the two domes. The answer is yes. Entry to Gardens is free and there are three main paid exhibits - the two domes (glasshouses) and the skyway. Get used to everything in Singapore being $28! This is the price to access the domes, so we chose not to do so as one was closed for maintenance. However, as a group, we paid $8 each and walked the Skyway. It provides great views and probably worth its money. Allow a couple of hours and stroll around Gardens By The Bay. Read up on the conservatories, and if they interest you, pay the money and head in. Enjoy.

REVIEW_TITLE: Take advantage of the free guided tours by volunteers and a discount if you are flying Singapore Airlines
REVIEW_BODY:
Had a great tour of the buildings before hitting the actual galleries. The building histories are amazing and the free guide very informative and knowledgeable. Tour is supposed to take an hour, but as there were only a few of us the guide kept on showing us stuff. You can see the room where the Japanese signed the surrender of Singapore after WW2 - the same room where the republic of Singapore was declared - twice. Old court rooms and holding cells as well as the modern architecture drawing two colonial buildings together. Tip from a local is to go back there after 4pm as there is a bar on the roof top where you get a panoramic view of Singapore (I'm trying that next time)._x000D_
_x000D_
Saw the art and empire exhibition - excellent. The gallery has the best and most comprehensive collection of South East Asian art._x000D_
_x000D_
If you arrive or depart on Singapore Airlines or can show your Krisflyer membership there is a 10% discount._x000D_
_x000D_
Will definitely visit again next time I am in Singapore.
ADDRESS: 1 St. Andrew's Road #01-01 National Gallery Singapore, Singapore 178957, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: GREAT ZOO FOR KIDS AND ADULTS
REVIEW_BODY:
The zoo is absolutely beautiful stunning and the setting and open pocket natural settings are just great to get away from the noise of the city._x000D_
_x000D_
I have however some feedback for management._x000D_
_x000D_
I usually never watch a zoo "show" as i believe that the shows are awful and dont like the animals to be trained for human entertainment. Yes i know that from the managements's point of view, the animals are just doing what they would do in nature. I still stand by my point of view and rather not watch a circus show in the zoo._x000D_
I sat in 2 shows however in the last 3 weeks because i brought visitors from overseas to the zoo. I could hardly listen to what the host was saying as they speak so fast and in such a bad tone that one is unable to listen to what they are saying. The speakers are also outdated and one is able to hear the commentary but its not clear to listen to. Perhaps management needs to invest in better digital speakers. Management should also record the commentary of the host at the shows and play it back to them to see if the host follow and understand what they are saying. I spoke to a host after the show about the commentary and she said nobody really listens anyway and shrugged me off as a silly tourist._x000D_
_x000D_
The only time u get attention from a staff member is when they annoyingly try and take pictures of you and sell you the same afterwards. Most tourist and people visiting these attractions usually have their own cameras and annoying selfie sticks with flash taking their own pictures. Why have your staff "crying" out annoyingly to sell a photograph._x000D_
Its sad that this once amazing animal sanctuary attraction is now nothing more than a money spinning business._x000D_
_x000D_
Perhaps some improvement on the signage of animals and more educative information as well. Not much to read about the animals._x000D_
_x000D_
A question for management, why is ticket booth signage translated only into chinese? and not any other language. Are tourist from other countries not good enough for your business? Singapore is an English speaking country and english is a universal language and i do believe that signage should be only in english in singapore. Perhaps i am wrong.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

We went to this place yesterday and walked for 7.8 kilometers (above 10,000 steps)._x000D_
_x000D_

The one I use was no. 980 which drop me right in front which very close to car parking area on Lornie Road. On you right hand there's restroom, Cafe and Drinks Kios. In case you forget to bring water. You just stop here first to buy drink. It won't be other Kios along the way._x000D_
_x000D_
Both me and my hubby, we just did boardwalk along the water. I was very nice and peaceful. This place wasn't busy even on Sunday afternoon._x000D_
_x000D_
We only saw a few butterflies and a dozen of monkeys yesterday. Monkey weren't friendly here. You can't get to close. Do not carry plastic bag with you. If they see plastic bag they will come right to you and try to take it away. Put everything in your bagpack is best. Looking at them from distance and use zoom in camera was enjoyable enough._x000D_
_x000D_
Personally, I preferred walking around here than botanical garden. Definitely we will be back again soon.

REVIEW_TITLE: Gardens by the bay with 3 kids
REVIEW_BODY: This is a great place to visit. It is immaculately maintained and a great way to spend a few hours. Aside from the gardens themselves, there are so many other attractions within them or next to them. It does get very hot but there are plenty of places to find shelter or refreshment. I recommend coming in the evening and watching the light show in the trees, which is amazing and the kids loved it. THe shows start at 19:45 and 20:45 (check in case they change) but get there a good 10 or 15 minutes before as the area does fill up quick. Most people sit or lay on the ground to watch the show that lasts 15 minutes. You can also watch it from the tree walkway, which you have to pay to go up to. Make sure you also visit the Cloud Forest.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Considering Singapore lies in the heart of the tropics, in an area known for its rainforests, itâ€™s hardly surprising that an important section of the Gardens by the Bay should be devoted to rainforests. This is a massive greenhouse called the Cloud Forest. We entered this when it was already getting dark, and therefore couldnâ€™t appreciate the flowers as well as we perhaps would have been able to had we reached during daylight hours._x000D_
_x000D_
The first sight that greets you when you enter is a high waterfall (the tallest indoor one in the world). From beyond this, elevators rise several stories to the top, bringing you out at the top of the waterfall. Here, once youâ€™ve admired the view from the top, you can start going downâ€”through a series of walkways that coil around the â€˜mountainâ€™ that forms the basis of the forest. At each level, there is some explanatory text to show how rainforests survive and what they consist of, what are their features, and so on. More than that, of course, there are the plants and trees themselves. Orchids, especially, are in profusion here._x000D_
_x000D_
Among the noteworthy sections in the Cloud Forest are the Crystal Mountain (which showcases crystals, the mining of which is a factor in the decimation of rainforests) and the Secret Garden, which is a recreation of a Jurassic era landscape, including miniature orchids so tiny that they are displayed behind carefully placed magnifying glasses!_x000D_
_x000D_
The ground floor of Cloud Forest houses a souvenir shop which includes, besides postcards and the like, some very pretty mementoes crafted from flowers and foliageâ€”especially tiny magenta orchidsâ€”from the gardens._x000D_
_x000D_
The ticket for Cloud Forest is included in the entry fee for the Flower Dome, so hang on to it if you want to see both sights.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | 18 Marina Gardens Drive, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: I have been meaning to get to Gardens by the Bay for some time and by chance was out walking around the marina and popped in. So happy I did. It cost SGD16 to get into the Cloud Forest but is so worth it. It's all air-conditioned and the plants/flowers on display are amazing. You walk in to the bottom of a waterfall and then catch a lift up to the top. Every 2 hours they produce mist which cover the mountain, it's a sight to behold. There is a walkway you can use to walk all around the mountain, I am not keen on heights but still pushed myself through it twice. Once when the mist was happening and once prior. I would definitely recommend to anyone travelling to Singapore.

REVIEW_BODY:
If you are staying in Singapore overnight then you must not miss the Light Show put on in the Gardens by the Bay. This starts at 7.45pm every night and admission is free. The easiest way to get there is by taxi which drops you off at the entrance. The walk in isn't too long and is accessible by everyone. It pays to get there a little early as every man and his dog goes an positions fill up!_x000D_

REVIEW_TITLE: The highlight of our Singapore holiday!
REVIEW_BODY:
THIS IS A MUST SEE IN SINGAPORE !_x000D_
If you see nothing else in Singapore you must spend at least 4 hours here._x000D_
Incorporating 2 glass houses and an outdoor garden; try and arrange the outdoor area walk when it is not raining as we did on suggestion by a guide. You are fully protected from the rain once inside one of the two domed glasshouses(largest in the world)._x000D_
The outdoor garden alone is beautiful (look for the beautiful palm walk, peaceful meadow and pond of colourful goldfish) but the jewel in the crown is the Cloud Forest._x000D_
We also had a light lunch at Pollen in the flower dome which was nice and reasonably priced for Singapore. There are plenty of discreet eating options inside the entire complex._x000D_
We missed the light show this time but did the sky walk at an additional $8S each._x000D_
We took two teens to this amazing place and never had one complaint. I think they were actually blown away!_x000D_
Gardens by the Bay is an absolute credit to Singapore and should be widely acclaimed.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Now this is extraordinary it was the first in the world and the novelty of it is great. However, it is at night and some animals are difficult to see or are timid obviously, although a tapir walked right past us!! They are animals though, it's always going to be random of how it is._x000D_
_x000D_
It's difficult to say what I made of it. You can see there nocturnal animals and they are great but pics are near impossible unless using a top of the line slr so sitting back and enjoying the ride is good. They take you around on these coach/buggie things and you can get off to walk bits if you want._x000D_
_x000D_
There is also a show where the trainers demonstrate some of the animals traits and skills in an informative way. This was very very good._x000D_
_x000D_
My advice;_x000D_
It opens at 7:30 if I remember and is near the river safari it's well sign posted. Turn up early, we turned up at 7 and the queue was the length of the courtyard which is huge. The staff are great at getting a lot of people through but be prepared to wait a while if you're not willing to stand in line for so long._x000D_
_x000D_
Also the food is mega expensive at the zoo. Bring your own and drinks if you can._x000D_
_x000D_
On finishing the night safari we needed a taxi back. From doing this twice it is important if you don't want to queue for ages then sit at the back of the show so you're first out and then walk quick to the rank near the entrance. There will be a lot but there are also loads of people coming out at the same time too._x000D_
_x000D_

REVIEW_BODY: I used to come here quite often when I was younger as I am from just across the causeway. But over the years this road has changed a lot. It used to be very affordable shopping here, but now the road is deck with plenty of upmarket designer brands that it has lost my attraction. For those who can afford it this road is a haven for you. Brands from Gucci to Miu Miu and the likes in a few malls. This road has a lot of malls having the same designer brands.....so if you decided later to buy something from a brand all you to do is go in the next mall. I am sure there will be another branch there. The last time I came here was just before Christmas. There were quite good discounts but the crowd was pure madness. I suggest if you want to come here, use the MRT during festive season or weekends. If you intend to use Grab.... forget it. Parking is also expensive around here. Unless you want to park quite a distance away and walk to this road. All in all, if you haven't come here before please do at least once. (great for people watching at least)

From a connectivity perspective, You should take the North South line (Red line - North) and get down at Ang Mo Kio Junction. From there would need to take route 138 bus. REVIEW_BODY: We saw these being built during our last trip to Singapore in 2013 and couldn't wait to see them this trip. We where not disappointed and arrived at 4pm allowing at least an hour for each the Cloud Forest & Flower Garden domes.You do have to experience these to appreciate how amazing they both are. I also think it was extra special going on the 2nd week of December as they where dressed for Christmas. We also booked dinner at IndoChine which is a restaurant positioned at the top of teh nlargest Super Tree in the Super Tree Grove. This was our best highlight during this visit and I would suggest it to any one. You can also have a couple of evening drinks on the roof top bar 1st and watch the sun set with the Marina Bay Sands and city as your back drop ! Again there was a special light show in the Super Tree Grove each evening for Christmas and it was a spectacle in itself - Definitely a MUST DO when in Singapore !

REVIEW_BODY:
Service, variety and luxury pretty much sum this place up. It is like a medium sized city all in one place and super convenient to everything. One of the top ten resort hotels I have stayed in world wide. Not cheap for sure, but if you can afford it you will not be disappointed. My only constructive feedback would be on the quality of pillows provided. I am allergic to feathers and requested a foam pillow and what I got was pretty disappointing. Large and hard. Having just come from China on this trip and staying at a Hyatt, I would have to say this was a negative. When you are spending this much per night, I would expect a quality pillow, not a budget one. As you spend almost a 3rd of your day sleeping, this is a key part of a 4 star rating for me seeing as I am spending a week and did not bring my own pillow from home. Sore neck in the morning and not feeling rested is a bummer._x000D_
_x000D_
The rooftop infinity pool is amazing, but you need it to unwind your stiff neck.
ADDRESS: 10 Bayfront Avenue | Level 57, Marina Bay Sands Hotel, Singapore 018956, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
This is probably the highest pedestrian overhead bridge in Singapore, and the most beautiful._x000D_
If you face south, you could see the almost mesmerising architectural wonder that is Reflections at Keppel Bay._x000D_
If you head east, you could walk your way to Mount Faber. If you walk west, you would be walking high on top of the forest, on a almost 2km Tree-top Walk called the Forest Walk towards the Alexander Arch._x000D_
The bridge floor feels like a giant boardwalk and there are seats for you if you are tired._x000D_
Of course at night, the view is even more beautiful, it's cool and the walks are simply not to be missed.
ADDRESS: 221 Henderson Road Henderson Building, Singapore 159557, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Disappointed with our trip to the Night Safari which was a highly anticipated excursion on our holiday. Booked an 8:15 session and arrived 1/2 hour earlier in case of any queues. Well we queued for 1.5 hours to get to the ticket booth and then a further half hour to get on a tram!! Everyone cheered when each tram moved off - don't think it was excitement at seeing the animals.._x000D_
_x000D_
This delay meant we didn't get to see the shows, try the walking tours or feeding of the animals as we'd run out of time._x000D_
_x000D_
The larger animals also seemed bored - it's difficult to make out the enclosure size / stimulants - in the dark but their behaviour left us a bit worried._x000D_
_x000D_
When we asked our children (7 & 9) if they enjoyed it they said it was good but not worth the 2 hour wait for a 30 minute ride._x000D_
_x000D_
Possibly due to the time of year we went but ticket sales should have been limited to avoid the chaos.

REVIEW_BODY:
My wife and I took a taxi to Singapore zoo in a premium taxi from the Intercontinental in Bugis early on a Sunday morning and it took c. 20 mins and cost $25 (note the return in a normal taxi was $21.50). _x000D_
_x000D_
We had pre-booked tickets online and had printed copies which saved time. We arrived at 8.15am. Park entry opened at 8.30am and we made our way to Breakfast with Orangutans at Ah Meng restaurant (cost $35 per person with payment on entry, cards accepted). Breakfast was of very average quality (when compared to the 5* hotels weekend staying in but was edible). However, the opportunity to get up close to the orangutans (they come out 9.30am-10am) is really what you're paying for. You can take photos while they sit on their perch eating their breakfast and then there is the opportunity for you to have your photo taken with them.  (Note that your photo is first taken by the zoo photographer and you can pay silly money to have it printed out but there is a second who will take a picture with your own camera). The experience is not as intimate as depicted on the website but there must have been approx 140 people there. Nevertheless, we thoroughly enjoyed the experience. I didn't take comparable quality photos seeing them in their activity area later on in the day. _x000D_
_x000D_
The rest of the day we explored the rest of the zoo. We went to the sea lion show at 10.30am and sat towards the front. We had a great view. Note you will get wet if you sit in the blue benches in the first two rows. The show was really good fun. Get there early to secure a good seat. _x000D_
_x000D_
Then onto the elephant show at 11.30am. Once again, we arrived early and had a seat towards the front. The show was really entertaining. _x000D_
_x000D_
We then went alround seeing most of the animals: gibbons, hippos, white tiger, lions, giraffe, zebra etc. All good fun. I like the fact that animals aren't caged up but are given as much freedom as possible to roam around. _x000D_
_x000D_
There are numerous toilets and water points throughout the zoo. We had lunch at KFC in the kid zone (where there is a water 'park' that looked like great fun for the kids). Note it's cash only. There is a "tram" which only stops at the four designated stops around the zoo - so not that great for getting around as you'd miss a lot out. Much better to take it easy and walk around. We entered the park at 8.30am and left at 2.30pm after seeing most of what we wanted to see. _x000D_
_x000D_
We thoroughly enjoyed our time at the zoo. The best we've ever been to and a well deserved 5*. Highly recommended.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: A pleasant walk with some interesting features
REVIEW_BODY: We started this walk from the cathedral end and continued around the bay to the Marina bay mall. There are lots of great views along the way, with gardens on the land side housing great sculpture pieces, the Singapore symbol spouting water into the marina, river cruises around the bay, a lot of restaurants and bars, and numerous seating areas to rest the weary feet. There is a breeze across the water so it doesn't feel blistering hot even at midday. If you are lucky you may see some otters, and there are lots of turtles basking on the wooden struts under the broadwalk. It gets very busy at the weekend so keep that in mind if you'd like a quieter stroll.

REVIEW_TITLE: A moving tribute to all those how gave up their lives
REVIEW_BODY: We took the MRT to Kranji then about a 20 minute walk to the memorial. Like other WW2 memorials and cemeteries (we have visited many in Belgium and France) the cemetery is immaculately maintained. It is an excellent tribute to all those who gave up their lives. To give more meaning to our visit, we took a name at random out of the headstone register then looked for the name on the memorial and his headstone. This gave more meaning to our visit and personalised it a little. It helps you realise just how many people gave up their lives. We feel a place of the internet gives wider and deserved recognition to our chosen (unknown to us) person who sacrificed his life. Hence our photo of the headstone of Lieutenant P. S. Turner of the Malaya Police below. He died age 24. May he Rest In Peace
ADDRESS: 9 Woodlands Road, Singapore 738656, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: This was a fascinating visit, and very much brought to life for us the surrender of Singapore to the Japanese. The guide, whose own parents lived through the occupation ,was well informed and interesting. It was acknowledged that although there was ultimately little choice, the decision makers, symbolised by chillingly life- like models seated round the table in earnest discussion, had the burden of this on their shoulders for the rest of their lives. It was inconceivable to imagine so many soldiers cramped together in the dank, poorly ventilated accommodation. The rooms and labrynthine passages inside the carefully concealed building had thick walls to protect the accommodation from an assault but there were few toilet facilities and comforts . Probably one of the most realistic and evocative wartime museums I have experienced.
ADDRESS: 2 Cox Terrace | Fort Canning Park, Singapore 179622, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
My husband and I toured the gardens by the bay and enjoyed our time their; roughly 3 hours. After paying $18 SGD per person to get into the flower dome and the cloud forest, we entered. I was very impressed by the structure itself. The glass and steel dome is incredible. I was also really impressed with the size of the trees that were inside the flower dome. Lots of great photo opportunities. Look for the European olive trees. The cloud forest has some great vignettes of flowers; the carnivorous plant display was my favorite. The temperature in the domes was also a lot cooler than I had expected. It was a welcome break from the Singapore heat and humidity._x000D_
_x000D_
What the domes lacked, was any real information. We did not get the audio tour so maybe this was our mistake but there is any significant signage describing the mission of the gardens, why they chose the plants they chose, and any real major facts about specific plants. I was especially disappointed with the final exhibit of stalagmites and stalactites. There was barely any explanation about them and nothing about where these samples were from, etc...really disappointing._x000D_
_x000D_
Overall, a fun walking tour but didnâ€™t really learn anything new or exciting about what I saw, which was a bummer.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Singapore Garden Festival + Singapore Orchid Show = What a Treat!
REVIEW_BODY:
Just visiting the Gardens by the Bay is in itself a feast for the eyes and the senses, but add to that, the annual Singapore Orchid Show makes it doubly so. Sadly the Festival ends in July, but the Orchid Extravaganza extends to 28 August 2016._x000D_
We used to rave over the Chelsea Flower Show in London, but hey, this is just as good, and if you wish to see different species of dendrobiums, catalyas, and especially philaenopses, don't delay._x000D_
The hybrids from regional breeders alone are worth the visit...Look out for the prize winners. The trophies they win are there for all to see, and comment._x000D_
If you are already there, you should also experience the Cloud Forest which is located adjacent to the Flower Dome. The man-made waterfall is 5 stories high. If you suffer from vertigo, bring a loved one to hold your hand! Even if you do not, the hand-holding will still be fun!
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Great Views. (Top 3 things to do in Singapore)
REVIEW_BODY:
If you are in Singapore, then a visit to the Singapore Flyer is a must. The ride last 30 mins and the entire gondola (as they are called) is quite big and can accommodate 15 people atleast. if you are scared of heights, then maybe avoid but I would still ask you to go and sit in the middle of the seating area where you wont feel the height._x000D_
The ride is expensive though (costs about 33 Singapore dollar per person) and the first 25% of the ride does not really have any interesting views except for the view of the ocean, part of the Singapore grand prix track and Gardens by the bay. It is only once Gardens by the Bay comes, that all the sights including, the Marina Bay, the Singapore Skyline, Merlion Park, Esplanade, Helix Bridge, Marina Bay etc. are viewed with a mind boggling views. Get yourself clicked as many times with these different views in the background._x000D_
_x000D_
The one complaint I had though was the entire approach to actually finding the flyer is not very well designed and there should be many signboards. Also, the gift shops needs to have small models of the flyer to take back home and the staff in the gift shop could be a little more courteous._x000D_
_x000D_
There is also the option of visiting it in the night and getting a different view of the same things with the lighting but due to the cost it might not justify going twice. Better to take a pic of the flyer from far when it is lit which itself is quite beautiful
ADDRESS: 30 Raffles Avenue, Singapore 039803, Singapore

The first and greatest delight of the visit is the magnificent architecture of the museum and the now attached old law courts. The cost to visit was reasonable $20sg. Lower for students or those over 60._x000D_
_x000D_
The whole set up is marvellous with exhibitions that change over time. There was a minimalist exhibition on when I was there and each to there own it was just that. The exhibition by the artist, Lim was magnificent, showing those with talent donâ€™t need to be minimalist. Other works of art included beautiful sculptures and paintings outlining the history of Singapore and events that shaped this nation._x000D_
_x000D_
The law courts now connected by sky bridges are quite fascinating, you see the many areas, objects and manuscripts that guided and controlled Singapore._x000D_
_x000D_
Go for it all but especially go for the architecture.
ADDRESS: 93 Stamford Road National Museum of Singapore, Singapore 178897, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
We went to the river safari and night safari with our 3 kids under 10 and two grandparents. A number of exhibits on the river safari were closed (all the walk through ones) and the giant pandas which were highly advertised were barely visible. We bought tickets to the amazon river cruise which upon arrival at the start of the ride (a one minute walk from the ticket counter) we were informed it would not go ahead due to the incoming storm. It seems pretty clear when selling the tickets a storm was imminent! We were then told we could not get a refund on the boat ride but could get a credit for the gift store. Upon complaining we were allowed to use it towards food. The river safari was largely fish in tanks with a few varieties of alligator and Turtles thrown in. The manatees were enjoyable._x000D_
We were booked on the 7.15pm Night Safari which also included a live show. We went through the gate at 7pm and were told the 7.15pm live show was now full but we could see the 8.15pm after our safari - all good. We then got ushered into an enormous queue which we stood in for 45min with our kids and elderly parents. We finally got into the tour at 7.45pm. The tour was 30min long and underwhelming. Upon finishing the safari we were told the 8.30pm live show was full and we could wait for the 9.30pm show. We could not wait around that long with 3 small kids._x000D_
It feel as though the zoo has simply sectioned off parts of the zoo which has enabled them to charge 3 entry fees. The much anticipated night tour was disorganised and extremely underwhelming. Spend your money doing something else.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: Singapore is an amazing modern city comprised of diverse communities living in relative harmony and mutual respect. One of the glittering cities of the new Asia, it is hard to imagine what it was like for the poor immigrants of the 19th and early 20th centuries - mostly from China, but from other places as well - who struggled to survive and raise families. Somewhat like the Tenement Museum in NYC, a visitor gets a vivid sense of how difficult life truly was for these newcomers. The shophouses of Singapore (many of the remaining ones have have been remade into upscale bars and restaurants) housed businesses on the street level, the family living above, and newcomers crowded into awfully basic quarters above that. It is very well presented, and an important reminder of how much anonymous effort went into creating the foundations of this now world-class metropolis.
ADDRESS: 48 Pagoda Street, Singapore 059207, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
The design of this place is unbelievable- absolutely incredible. Allow yourself 2 days to fully appreciate it - though it is possible to see most of it in one day it you would be a bit rushed! The two domes are amazing, Flower and Cloud, and you have to pay to enter them but a reasonable price. If you have a coffee in the Pollen Cafe you get free entry into the flower dome ( usually costs 16 Singapore dollars) The cloud dome is huge and impressive with many different unusual plants and a massive waterfall!_x000D_
At night the whole place becomes magical with a light show from the 'trees' to music twice each evening._x000D_
There is also a small kiddies water park with jets of water spraying - no pool but there are changing facilities. There are various sculptures dotted around the park some of which are quite thought provoking._x000D_
There is also plenty of places to eat and drink, even a macdonalds, and gift shops._x000D_
Access to the gardens is easy being approx 20 minute walk from the cruise ship terminal or by underground train (MRT) to ' Bayfront' station._x000D_
No visit to Singapore would be complete without at least a day spent here!
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Don't forget your kids swimming dress!
REVIEW_BODY: Singapore Zoo is a lovely animal park which succeeds binging the animals as close to you as modern zoo infrastructure allows. Special theme shows (time limited) let you explore new things - even if you have been there before. I enjoyed the Australia theme and I loved how they had flipped the concept so that visitors had to stay on a trail and animals could go everywhere. Finally if your kids need a break and cool off there also is a little water play area which is fun. There is a pet circus too and of course a little toy store. Its a great half to one day out in the wild for the whole family.

REVIEW_BODY: Certainly the most iconic views of the Singapore skyline are from the 'ship' on the top of marina bay sands. You need to pay ?23SD for a 'drinks voucher' which you can use to purchase a drink (although cocktails at 24SD - ends up being 28SD with the 17% tax, Tiger beers are 16SD or 18.70 with 17% tax). REVIEW_BODY:
I organised a Family Day event for my church on September 10, 2016 at The Singapore Zoo. The day started with a heavy shower in the morning. The downpour stops by the time we arrived at The Zoo. The morning shower cools the day for us._x000D_
_x000D_
We were warmly greeted at the entrance by welcomers. As we walked in, I noticed zoo workers sweeping away puddles of water. This is a rare sight in many places I visited. The Singapore Zoo was well kept, neat and signages strategically placed to direct visitors to the various sectors of the zoo._x000D_
_x000D_
There are animals of Australasia, Africa, Borneo and many other countries. You can even find a polar bear in this tropical zoo. It was a good learning experience for the young as many have not seen so many animals from different countries. For the more senior visitors, they remarked their last visit was more than 15 years ago._x000D_
_x000D_
After walking for about 2 hours, we assembled at Ah Meng Terrace to rest our tired feet and have our lunch which was catered from the restaurant there. The food was good and well balanced. The restaurant management cordoned off a section of the covered terrace for our "private function"._x000D_
_x000D_
After the lunch, most of us left the Singapore Zoo in our charted coaches. A number of our members stayed on to watch the animal shows in the afternoon. It takes about 4 hours to cover the whole zoo. There is a tram service (free for senior citizens) that brings you around the zoo._x000D_
_x000D_
The Singapore Zoo is one of the best zoo have visited. Besides the animals, there is also a wide collection of flora for us to enjoy. Every section and specie of flora and fauna is well explained on plaques. There are friendly wardens who are ever ready to help if you need assistance.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

If you have young children, itâ€™ll take you 2-3 days just to cover the 4 wildlife parks in the country, starting with Singapore zoo._x000D_
This zoo is a shining example for what zoos across the world should be. And they know how to market themselves too. Shows, feeding sessions, themes, terrific._x000D_
The zoo itself isnâ€™t huge. But is very well designed and accessible. Trams arrive continuously and maps are well detailed._x000D_
Orangutans are the highlight of the zoo, and the zoo makes the most of that recognition._x000D_
Itâ€™ll take atleast 6-7 hours to cover the zoo, with a few shows thrown in. Plan accordingly._x000D_
The best thing is the staff. Wonderfully trained, patient, and knowledgeable. Well done, Singapore Zoo
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: The gardens not to be missed
REVIEW_BODY: We watched the light show from Marine Bay Hotel which was a little disappointing, so we went to the gardens in daylight. The gardens are well organised and beautiful set out, although when we visited in "November " the amount of bloom was a little subdued. However the sculptures scattered throughout the gardens were outstanding and well worth a closer look. The two domes "The Flower Dome" and the " The Cloud Forest" were fantastic and easily made up for the lack of blooms in the main gardens. The OCBC SKYWAY is a very unusually way to view the gardens as it is about 22metres off the ground, and very cleverly constructed to show off the gardens to the best.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: A must see - only place like it in the world
REVIEW_BODY:
Our trip to Gardens by the Bay was the highlight of our days in Singapore. It's truly a world class attraction, unlike any other botanical garden I've ever encountered. It's divided into two major wings - the Cloud Forest and the Flower Dome._x000D_
_x000D_
Cloud Forest is its own self-contained ecosystem and a masterwork in landscape architecture - you often find yourself wondering where the artistry of God and nature begins and the art of man begins. The Flower Dome renders all of the world's different flower kingdoms before the visitor, with impressive setting and backgrounds to match._x000D_
_x000D_
The light show in the Supertree Garden is not to be missed; the arbor of metal puts on a symphonic light show to set off an evening in Singapore. Easily the highlight of our two weeks in Southeast Asia and worth every penny.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Gardens by the bay is beautiful and very accessible. You can take a bus, MRT, taxi or walk from the Marina Bay Sands shopping centre. It is accessible for wheelchairs and pushchairs._x000D_
_x000D_
Gardens are free to enter and have pathways to go through, there's a children's garden and a light show at the Tree groves; which is not to be missed. The light show is magical and happens at 8pm everyday (I think - we went on Sunday)._x000D_
_x000D_
There are paid activities such as:_x000D_
_x000D_
1) The bridge between the Tree Groves; you can walk through them and enjoy the views. We didn't go on them as the queue was very long and also because pushchair wasn't allowed up there._x000D_
_x000D_
2) The Flower Dome is a must, they have floral exhibitions there. We saw hundreds of beautiful orchids in different colours, shapes and sizes. The preservation is praise worthy in the climate controlled domes._x000D_
_x000D_
3) The cloud forest comes in the same ticket as the flower domes. It has a beautiful waterfall at the entrance is quite cold inside. The dome has a lift to go up and there's a walk way to come down seeing different plants and trees. The preservation again is praise worthy as some of the plants won't even survive in the Singapore climate._x000D_
_x000D_
There are restaurants inside so you don't have to worry about food. We had a great experience and Gardens by the bay should be on your top list when visiting Singapore. It takes around 3 hours to see all of the things inside both domes and the Tree Groves.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Absolutely stunning views of Harbourfront and Sentosa! :)
REVIEW_BODY:
I spent an hour and a half taking pictures and hiking from Mount Faber to Hort Park after getting off the cable car at Mount Faber station. The view at the top of Faber Point, the highest point of the park, was simply stunning and offered a wonderfully picturesque view of Harbourfront and Sentosa._x000D_
_x000D_
There is plenty of gorgeous greenery and wildlife such as monkeys to explore along the way (I managed to get a good photo of a cute squirrel). Do make sure to bring some mosquito spray with you as unfortunately they are part of the wildlife as well! Drinking fountains are available along the hiking trail if you want to fill up your water bottle or you forgot to bring one in the first place and need to quench your thirst._x000D_
_x000D_
On my walk, I passed through the artistic Henderson Waves bridge, which is the highest pedestrian bridge in Singapore (274m in length and 36m above ground). There were plenty of benches here to relax and rest my feet for a while. Further along, there is an awesome forest walk where you can admire the lush green scenery below and around you. Alexandra Arch, located just before Hort Park, has an interesting shape just like an open leaf. I definitely recommend the journey from Mount Faber to Hort Park for nature lovers! :)
ADDRESS: 109 Mount Faber Road Faber Peak | Faber Peak, Singapore 099203, Singapore

We started at the northern end via the Botanic Gardens MRT station and slowly meandered south towards the Orchid Garden. As well as as enjoyed the plants along the way, you can take in extra exhibits like the Evolution Garden which tells the story of how plants have evolved on our planet._x000D_

Highly recommended.

REVIEW_BODY:
I imagine a giant starring through the glass pieces of a giant ant farm at all the little ants walking up and down a mountain with a waterfall in it, up and down, up and down - wondering what are these little ants up to._x000D_
_x000D_
That was my thoughts as I walked the cloud forest - you just feel small inside this massive man-made forest with the most beautiful vegetation and this towering man-made waterfall spraying over you as you walk in. Then you start your journey, ever so slowly up and round and the various walkways till you reach the top only to find a few more surprises there!_x000D_
_x000D_
I really wasn't expecting much - I mean itâ€™s a giant greenhouse after all but it is spectacular and worth every minute spent! Not only that it provides welcome relief from the Singapore heat and we found we easily spend 1 1/2 hours in there without realizing it. Make sure you check what times the actual clouds of the cloud forest are switched on and make sure you are at the top when it starts!_x000D_
_x000D_
I would definitely recommend this to anyone, YES even us manly men can enjoy a garden!!

REVIEW_BODY: I read the reviews prior to heading to the Night Safari and I was a little apprehensive - it sounded expensive for what you saw. Was I wrong! Get an early time because I was there for three + hours. They shuffle you in and like sheep everyone heads to the shuttle bus or the show. I saw the show which was excellent! Then like sheep again was herded to the shuttle bus. The animals are extraordinary!!! Once the bus is finished, everyone follows each other to the exit. Don't do it!! Divert from the crowd and follow the walking trail - I can't explain to you how amazing the walking trail is, so many animals missed from the bus tour. It's the walking tour where the real animal experience is at!!

REVIEW_TITLE: Mid-Autumn Festival at the Gardens by the Bay (6 - 24 Sep 2018)
REVIEW_BODY:
Visit in the late evening and enjoy the sights of the lighted lanterns as the sky turns dark. Proceed to the Supertree Grove, find a place to sit or lie down, and enjoy the display of light and sound. After the light and sound show, admire the lighted up "The Phoenix and the Peony", which symbolizes nobility, harmony and affluence._x000D_
Visit the Flower Dome for themed garden settings, and the Cloud Forest where a waterfall and "mountain" cloaked in vegetation await you, or admire the views from the 22m-high Skyway.

REVIEW_BODY:

But most of all you get a great view of the Supertrees themselves and the beautiful flowers and shrubs in the vertical gardens._x000D_

REVIEW_BODY:
This tour brought vividly to life the final surrender of the British to the Japanese on the 15th February 1942._x000D_
Living in the UK we are aware of the conflict in Europe but not very knowledgeable regarding the fall of Malaya and Singapore._x000D_
Our two young guides were able to explain how the situation developed and what life was like in the underground command centre in an accessible and interesting way. They had an in-depth knowledge of the subject and despite being assessed by their more senior colleagues spoke clearly and confidently._x000D_
The underground bunker has some confined spaces so it is recommended to book a tour in advance._x000D_
Allow time to explore the Fort Canning Park which is a haven of tranquillity in a very busy city.
ADDRESS: 2 Cox Terrace | Fort Canning Park, Singapore 179622, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: One of the best wheel experiences I've been one. Fantastic views 360 of the Marina Bay., Singapore skyline, famous Marina Sands hotel, financial district and more. Sorry London, it beats your experience! When you enter make sure you purchase your ticket first on the ground floor level then take the escalator up to the entrance where you receive a friendly welcome, usual photograph sell but you can skip this if prefer to take your own and then you walk through an interesting area of how the flyer was built - great to know some facts and also fun for kids or if long queues. We went early evening, one of the best times to go as not busy and the sunset views are amazing, then the lights appear on all the buildings, really great. It rained at the start but added to the excitement with lightening flashes! Since the ride is 30 minutes plenty of time for photos and the weather to clear. Fair price and a worthwhile experience.
ADDRESS: 30 Raffles Avenue, Singapore 039803, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Fantastic but dedicate a whole day to it
REVIEW_BODY:
My partner and I visited the Jurong bird park during a recent visit to Singapore. Established in 1971 this is the worlds largest bird park containing various bird species from all corners of the world. As a bird fancier I couldn't miss it. Had a great time but underestimated the size of the park and the time it would take to go through it. Here are a few tips for those planning a visit here._x000D_
_x000D_
1. Getting here - The Jurong Bird Park is located in the Suburb of Jurong, which is located in the west of Singapore - far away from the tourist epicentre. We went via the MRT. You get on the green east-west line to 'Boon Lay'. This will eject you in a large shopping centre. Walk through this to the bus terminal and get on bus number 194. This runs in a loop and from the station it will be your first stop. Do the same backwards (if you miss catching the bus at the stop you were dropped off at you can walk under the highway to the opposite side of the road). Unfortunately getting here via the MRT takes quite some time - we spent around 1.5 hours each way from our hotel room on orchard road before we got into the park._x000D_
_x000D_
2. Cost - To purchase a ticket for Jurong it is 29 (adult), 19 (child) and 13 for a senior citizen. For what you get this is good value_x000D_
_x000D_
3. Food - There is two restaurants at the entrance to the park but both are quite overpriced as you would expect._x000D_
_x000D_
4. Weather dependent - The bird park is almost exclusively located outside which can be a problem with singapores often passing rainshowers._x000D_
_x000D_
5. Shows - There are a few shows but one that i would absolutely recommend is the 'King of the Skies' show which displays birds of prey such as vultures, flacons, eagles and hawks._x000D_
_x000D_
6. Time - This is where I really got it wrong. You really want around 4-5 hours in the park to cover everything. You will be surprised just how much stuff there is to do. When combined with significant travel times on the MRT you want to dedicate a whole day of your holiday to this bird park rather than thinking you can fit it into a half day slot._x000D_
_x000D_
Overall I had a really good time here and I wouldn't hesitate in recommending it to others.
ADDRESS: 2 Jurong Hill Jurong Bird Park, Singapore 628925, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Check the weather BUT a better alternative
REVIEW_BODY:
The viewing platform is closed at the slightest hint of a change in the weather. It was drizzling with rain when we arrived only to find it was shut._x000D_
A better alternative is to buy the 20S$ ticket to the 57th floor bar. Great views of the city and Gardens by the bay, right next to the famous infinity swimming pool AND you trade your ticket against purchase of a drink or food from the bar !! Excellent deal._x000D_

REVIEW_TITLE: Very impressive and grand temple, worth a visit
REVIEW_BODY: I quite like temples, my husband is not so keen. However, as this particular Buddhist temple was only a short walk from where we were staying in Chinatown, and it's rated #13 on TripAdvisor for things to see and do, I thought it was worth a look. Being 5-storeys high, it's a large and impressive building from a distance. Up close, you can peer straight through the open doors into the very colourful and impressive main prayer room. Visitors are most welcome and we were lucky enough to be there when the prayer room was full with monks and locals chanting, I believe it was a celebration for one of the Gods they pray to. We wandered up through the levels, one floor was a small museum with many Buddhist artefacts and valuables, another floor had life-sized figures of venerable Buddhist monks, the 4th floor is simply dazzling and incredibly ornate as it features a display of a tooth of the Buddha inside a solid gold stupa - there is so much gold on display, contrasting with the red decor, it's almost overwhelming. The rooftop garden is peaceful, there is a very large Prayer Wheel within a pavilion, surrounded by tropical plants and flowers, a small oasis. Definitely worth a look.
ATTRACTION_NAME: Buddha Tooth Relic Temple and Museum
ADDRESS: 288 South Bridge Road, Singapore 058840, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
We were looking for a WWII tour that provided the historical background of Singapore and elected to visit Fort Canning. A Tour of the Battlebox, the command centre for Singapore, was about to commence so we joined in. We were not disappointed and found the tour very informative and learnt many important points about the surrender of Singapore on 15 February 1942. The tour guide, Kamaliah, was very professional and knowledgeable and she explained that a new company had taken over the renovation and upkeep of the Battlebox in 2016._x000D_
We took the 'Story of Strategy and Surrender' tour and had the circumstances behind the Japanese invasion and subsequent surrender of Singapore by the British explained to us. There were many details that we were not aware of including the valiant defence of the vital NW coast of Singapore by the Australian 8th Division against the far superior Japanese forces led by the infamous General Yamashita._x000D_
Would recommend this tour followed by a walk around the grounds if you get time. There is a new MTR station being built at Fort Canning which will make it easier to take public transport to this location in the future.
ADDRESS: 2 Cox Terrace | Fort Canning Park, Singapore 179622, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
The Supertree Grove is absolutely incredible. It is the centrepiece of the stunning Gardens By The Bay and has to be seen to be believed._x000D_
I fist saw it on David Attenborough's Planet Earth 2 and couldn't believe my eyes. So it was the first pkace we went to once we'd checked into our hotel._x000D_
It consists of a couple of dozen massive steel tree frames, each one planted with different flowers, bushes and shrubs. It's one of the world finest vertical gardens._x000D_
You can climb up one on a lift and take a boardwalk from tree to tree for a close up view before going down another. Amazing views of the Supertree, the Gardens and the bay and city itself._x000D_
Take your time and stroll around them at the base as well. They are truly enchanting, one of the finest sights I have ever seen on my travels._x000D_
There's an unmissable sound and light symphony every evening. Do as the locals do, lie on your back and look up to enjoy the show! It is on twice each evening and lasts about 20 minutes. Totally free and is utterly captivating.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive Gardens By the Bay | Gardens by the Bay, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Do visit for a breathtaking view!
REVIEW_BODY:
It is not overtly "public". You can see these characteristic buildings from almost anywhere in Chinatown which is practically next door._x000D_
_x000D_
1. It costs S$6. You have to go inside at the basement close to the overpass. A man will sit inside a pretty small room - almost anonymously. You pay him. Then you take the lift up afterwards._x000D_
_x000D_
2. The Pinnacle@Duxton is an award-winning 50-storey residential development in Singapore's city center, next to the business district. The project features the world's two longest sky gardens of 500 metres each, on both the 26th and 50th floors._x000D_
_x000D_
3. You have access to the 50th floor. The views from there cover practically all of Singapore because you can go anywhere on the roof of the buildings which are connected by bridges (easy to see from the street, but not noticeable when you are on the roof._x000D_
_x000D_
4. Try to arrange a visit at around 5:30PM and stay until after sunset. The sun usually sets at between 7:00PM and 7:20PM depending on the time of the year._x000D_
_x000D_
It really is worth it - especially with children. They will awe at everything!
ADDRESS: 1 Cantonment Road The Pinnacle @ Duxton, Singapore 080001, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Hidden gem, this relatively new museum impresses
REVIEW_BODY: Houses an excellent collection of art work from south east Asia and Asia and general. The building comprises the former City Hall and the further Supreme Court buildings which have been painstakingly refurbished into a modern, lavish museum building. Lots of fine dining to choose from. The Keppel creativity center is great for kids who can try their hands on art expression. Don't miss the historical prison cells where prisoners used to be held below the court.
ADDRESS: 1 St. Andrew's Road #01-01 National Gallery Singapore, Singapore 178957, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Definitely a not to be missed experience
REVIEW_BODY: Even if you are not a lover of gardens/gardening this is an experience not to be missed. There are shuttle services available but if you are comfortable walking everywhere is easily accessible. The highlight for us was the Flower Dome, absolutely beautiful. Pay the 10 Singapore Dollars to access the Indochine Restaurant where you can climb one flight of stairs to the roof bar. The view of the gardens and across the bay and city area is amazing. We spent 8 hours at the Gardens and needed all that time to make the most of the experience. Would recommend eating in area no. 7 on the site map as there are 4 different restaurants there to suit all tastes (this area is just one flight of steps down from the Visitor Centre).

REVIEW_BODY:
Gardens by the Bay is a must-see. Iâ€™m really not a botanical person, but the appeal here is far more._x000D_
Cloud Forest (to me) was by far the most interesting place. Iâ€™d suggest you go to this attraction first and spend most of your time here. We found Many outstanding photo places. You may have to wait for people to move to get the optimal selfie/wefie. People were very helpful in offering to help take a picture_x000D_
Flower Dome was nice, but Iâ€™d suggest you take it if you have time. If you are into flowers, you will be in heaven._x000D_
Important note, if you are going on the OCBC Skyway, plan accordingly. They closed this off due to rain. You might completely miss out if there is a passing rainstorm (common on Singapore)._x000D_
Lastly, there is an evening concert. I thought this was a Must See, and it just happened by accident. Excellent light and music show. Among the best Iâ€™ve seen._x000D_
Lots of walking (far more than we thought). Bring your most comfortable walking shoes._x000D_
Donâ€™t let the high ticket prices put you off. This is very well done.

REVIEW_TITLE: A day out at the Jurong Bird Park
REVIEW_BODY: I brought my daughter and her friend who are 8 years old to the Jurong Bird Park during the school holiday. They had a great day exploring every single corner and visited all bird species there. They loved the close interaction opportunities with the free roaming birds in many of the enclosures. The explanation are clear, but they find it quite hard to spot some of the birds, especially the eagles. Itâ€™s a pity that the owl enclosure was closed. It used to be the most exciting part of the visit when they were much younger. They learned a lot at the Breeding and Research Centre too.

REVIEW_TITLE: With limited time, we just visited the domes
REVIEW_BODY:
I used to live and work in Singapore but never had the chance to visit Marina Bay Sands. (Oh the irony!) Now that I'm living in Melbourne and been telling everyone who's going to Singapore to visit Gardens by the Bay, I decided I had to go myself! So I brought my parents._x000D_
_x000D_
As we have limited time and energy (my parents can't walk for too long) we decided to visit just the domes._x000D_
_x000D_
In my opinion the cloud dome was the better half of the two but I might be biased. As you walk in you are greeted by a majestic man made waterfall which makes you feel like you are in a movie set. The walk on the elevated platforms around the "hill" of greenery is amazing with the mist.. (Mist timing is every hour if i recall correctly)_x000D_
_x000D_
The flower dome is like what the name suggests - so if you love flowers its probably like a paradise for you._x000D_
_x000D_
You can head to Satay by the Bay after for local food galore like we did but worth to mention that its hidden away and quite a fair bit of a walk..._x000D_
_x000D_
I wish we had more time and capacity to explore the whole place and comment overall but I would think the domes are good enough to visit. Tickets are $28 for both domes for each adult (non-Singaporean) and shuttle to the domes from the entrance if you are too lazy or tired to walk is $3.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: You need to make a reservation ahead, you don't need o pay until you get there. A full multi-cultural buffet breakfast is served from 9:00 till 09:30, then they bring out the animals. A whole family of orang utans, were sat on a plinth, not 2 meters from our table. Get there early for the best seats. They were entertaining, on their own, far more so than the commentator who seemed to like the sound of his own voice! The mandatory photographers were there, but they will also take a picture using your own phone, which is just as well, because we somehow lost the ones we had paid for (not at the zoo, perhaps in our travels) The rest of the zoo is very well kept, and I loved the apes who were able to climb trees above us seemingly without a cage, but don't worry, spikes keep them from climbing all the way down. Definitely pay the extra S$5 to use the train, it gets pretty hot there. But a nice zoo, well laid out, and I'll recommend it.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: How Many Teeth Did the Buddha Have?
REVIEW_BODY:
The Buddha Tooth Relic Temple is a large Buddhist temple on the corner of Sago Street and South Bridge Road in Singapore's Chinatown._x000D_
_x000D_
It is a large and ornate temple that is in daily use by local Buddhists, so if you visit please dress conservatively and be respectful._x000D_
_x000D_
This temple's main claim to fame is that it houses a tooth of the Lord Buddha. I mean no disrespect, but the normal adult human has 32 teeth and around the world there are hundreds of Buddhist temples that lay claim to one of those 32 teeth._x000D_
_x000D_
One thing that did surprise me here, as I live in Thailand and am used to visiting Buddhist temples, is that nobody, including the Buddhist monks, took off their shoes.
ATTRACTION_NAME: Buddha Tooth Relic Temple and Museum

I chose the ArtScience museum as I had two (not so interested) teenagers with me. But it was a pleasure to see the girls engrossed during the entire visit._x000D_
The exterior of the museum is beautiful and one wouldn't mind spending time outside the museum, soaking the sights of the Marina Bay. The huge exhibits, complete with digital technology, colours, light, sounds, notes tickled our senses. "Into the Wild" - is a immersive virtual experience more suited to kids, where you walk in the corridor with iPads._x000D_

REVIEW_TITLE: A great place to spend a day
REVIEW_BODY:
The public transport in Singapore is so efficient, we bought a three day Tourist pass and that enable us to take unlimited rides on MRT and buses. To get to the Zoo, we hopped on an MRT to Chao Chu Kang MRT station (1.5 hours from Orchard Road) and bus #927 (15min) that drops you directly at the front gates._x000D_
_x000D_
We bought our pass online via the Singapore Zoo website (S$55 per adult for 2 parks with5% discount if purchased online) and didnâ€™t have to queue at the long line at the Zoo. We did the Zoo and the River Safari on the one day, in my opinion, two parks is plenty for one day, unless you only spend a few seconds at each exhibit. There are so much to see and the sea lions (splash) show is a must. We also made the elephant show which was amazing to see these gentle giants work with their mahouts effortlessly. There are various feeding times for different animals, so it is good to plan your visit so you make the most of what you want to see. There is a tram (additional S$5 per adult) that takes you around the Zoo it is an easy way to get from one section to another. There is plenty of shade around the Zoo so although it could get quite hot and humid, the surroundings tree canopies offer good shelter while walking around. We had lunch at the Ah Meng restaurant that offered hawker type stalls with a variety of local food. The River Safari is only couple of minutes walk away from the Zoo, be sure to purchase the River Safari boat ride as some of the animals are only viewable from the boat ride S$5 per adult) you are able to go on the ride again as we missed some animals on one side. The queue could get quite long, but it is well worth the wait. There is another reservoir boat cruise that is included in the River Safari ticket but you donâ€™t to see any animals except the giraffes or the rhinos, if you are lucky. The giant fish tank with the Dugongs are awesome, I could easily sit there watching them all day in the air conditioned comfort! The pandas enclosure in the River Safari is also a highlight, they are so close you feel you can almost touch them! If you visit Singapore, the Zoo and parks are a definite MUST SEE!
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore
