REVIEW_BODY:
This Chinese themed park was back in the days (1990s) one of the iconic parks in Singapore. I remember childhood days at this park that was generally overcrowded and a little weird._x000D_
_x000D_
The park still retains it quirky nature but is now a little forgotten._x000D_
_x000D_
The 10 courts of hell was one memorable ride in the part (it was a boat ride into a dragon). That has shrunk and is now a cave that you walk into. Still interesting to see._x000D_
_x000D_
The park is like lost in time (with benches from the old days) and chinese statues and stories._x000D_
_x000D_
Entry is free and really convenient to get to (a 2 mins walk from Haw Par Villa MRT station)._x000D_
_x000D_
For those into the quirky and something off the beaten track, I would recommend this park. A strong sense of Chinese culture and flavour and a memorable walk back in time.
ADDRESS: 262 Pasir Panjang Road Haw Par Villa | 1-min walk from Haw Par Villa MRT Station, Singapore 118628, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Cloud forest yes, flower dome maybe, skip the floral fantasy
REVIEW_BODY:
We visited in the daytime and so stuck with the indoor part of the gardens to stay cool. Really liked the Cloud forest - it has a lovely waterfall and lots of pretty exotic and interesting plants which we took a leisurely two hours to visit. Next we went to the flower dome, with the seasonal exhibit of orchids. It is very beautiful exhibit - that we enjoyed, but could be skipped if you are short on time. Final, we visited the floral fantasy exhibit - which featured some lovely flowers and a 10 min â€œ4Dâ€ ride which is pretty much an infomercial for the Gardens. Unless you are planning a bunch of selfies with flowers or like infomercials, this was a total waste of money IMHO._x000D_
_x000D_
Since we were there in the middle of the day, we didnâ€™t do much outdoors. We hope to go back when it is cooler to see the outdoors and hopefully stay for a light show.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Lovely museum and intro to SE Asian history
REVIEW_BODY:
We visited on a Saturday morning and found that there were very few other patrons, which led us to wonder why. As it turns out, we must have just been early because the exhibits here are fantastic._x000D_
_x000D_
The museum has a wonderful permanent exhibit on the Tang shipwreck, which was a real eye opener for me, despite my many previous trip to SE Asia. The impressive pottery collection and beautifully crafted displays only enhanced the visit._x000D_
_x000D_
The most unexpected, and a very refreshing change, was an exhibit was titled "Ghost Nets". This was an exhibition meant to stir our curiosity but with a lovely modern flair - we saw sea creatures created from discarded fishing nets. The displays were all created by school children, and must remind us of the fragility of our planet and the human impact on it._x000D_
_x000D_
Many other delights await the visitor to this museum - I would heartily recommend it to all!
ADDRESS: 1 Empress Place Empress Place Building, Singapore 179555, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
We go to Singapore on regular holidays and on our first actually stayed in Little India but always got the bus up to Orchard Road and the other main attractions. So on this our 6th visit to Singapore we decided to go back to Little India and see what it was like._x000D_
_x000D_
Similar to visiting China Town really, i.e. lots of shops offering souvenirs and cheap goods. We also visited a temple (missed the big one) but the one we did go to was very interesting and had lots of people in various stages of prayer. Don't forget to take your shoes off!!!!_x000D_
_x000D_
Also visited a huge people's food hall where there was so much food on offer it was hard to choose, this was at close to the MRT station so not hard to find._x000D_
_x000D_
Also wandered into a large kinda department store (I guess) with several floors. This place had everything so I guess it's where the locals do all their shopping. My husband bought two shirts for $10.00 each and I thought they will probably wash like rags because they were so cheap, but after being home and getting washed several times they are still as good as new and look great. Next trip he will definitely be going back there for more._x000D_
_x000D_
If you are after gold, then Little India is definitely the place to go. Indian's love their gold and they have shop after shop of nothing but gold, not my style but I'm sure you can find something if you are into gold._x000D_
_x000D_
Well worth a visit, next time I will be looking out for the main temple.
ADDRESS: Serangoon Road, Singapore, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Smell the flowers and the trees at Singapore Botanical Gardens!
REVIEW_BODY: The Singapore Botanic Gardens is a 158-year-old tropical garden located at the heart of Singapore's shopping district -Orchard Road! It is one of three gardens, and the only tropical garden, to be honoured as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Its National Orchid Garden houses the largest orchid collection of 1,200 species and 2,000 hybrids. Its Admission free and opwns from 5 am to 12 midnite. Always a great place to walk after work or simply "smell the flowers" after a long and tiring day of shopping when in Singapore!

REVIEW_TITLE: Get the 4 park hopper deal for $79 includes tram rides
REVIEW_BODY:
I went through City Tours and got the 4 park hopper deal for $79. Safari line bus to and from the Zoo. Leaves City about 1pm but check times and returns around 8pm onwards. I enjoyed the tram ride around the zoo and went full circle the planned which stops to get on and explore more. After 3 hours at the zoo I went to the river safari. Interesting walk but the Amazon Quest boat ride was the highlight. The boat cruise was ordinary as the animals to spot were to far away. Binoculars are recommended._x000D_
After 2 hours slowing taking in the views I made my way next door to the Night safari. This was well attended and the lines were very long. Knowing where to redeem tickets is a definite advantage and get the Express tram ride for $10. This will get you to the front much quicker. You don't need to walk the 2 trails as the tram slows down enough to see the animals pretty close up especially in the free range areas. Amazing facts given by tour guide. Take lots of water and deodorant as it is very humid.

REVIEW_BODY: It's hard to find things to do as a Singaporean parent to satisfy the insatiable curiosity of my 7 and 5-year olds and we happened to be strolling around Fort Canning when we stumbled upon the poster for Battlebox. There are fixed timings to the tour, so you might want to check out their website to avoid disappointment. There's the 1-hour Battlebox tour and the 2.5 hours Battlebox and Fort Canning tour. My son is big on WWII stuff now so we brought him for his birthday and we had real fun. Our guide, Joanne, was friendly and informative and addressed the questions of his curious audience, which mostly consisted of Caucasian tourists. We took a short 3-minute walk to the start of the air-conditioned tunnels. It's definitely not a tour for screaming kids or those who might be inclined to claustrophobia. The tour was a mixture of presentation by Joanne and watching three videos. The best part of the tour was the parts of the tunnels which were from the time of the war (doors which were sliced to allow for more ventilation, Japanese writing etched on the wall, a generator of sorts). There are a lot of realistic wax sculptures and interesting production design to recreate the final days of WWII. Our guide told us about how they might be changing it to allow for a self-guided tour, though I kind of like the personal human-element of the tour. I craved more WWII artefacts to be on displayed within the tunnels. There's a nice store which sells interesting books at the end of the tour. I bought a thick book on The Fall of Singapore and two other books for my son, but I think I'm enjoying the books as much as he is.
ADDRESS: 2 Cox Terrace | Fort Canning Park, Singapore 179622, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: An underrated natural gem in a bustling metropolis! :)
REVIEW_BODY:
I visited these charming gardens on a Saturday and found the place to be wonderfully quiet and serene. This place is a definite must see for nature lovers! I reckon 3 hours is sufficient for a relaxing and leisurely stroll around both the Chinese and Japanese Gardens. Start with a climb up the 7-storey pagoda for a stunning panoramic view of Singapore, then make your way to the lovely twin pagodas._x000D_
_x000D_
There is a gorgeous bonsai garden located within the Chinese Gardens, where you can sit on a stone seat and admire the beautiful scenery. The Chinese Gardens also has a live tortoise and turtle museum (that deserves more love), which houses rare species from across the world. There is plenty of squirrel and bird watching to be done as well around the gardens. In fact, I managed to spot a Kingfisher, which was awesome!_x000D_
_x000D_
Once you have completed a full circuit of the Chinese Gardens, cross over the long white bridge into the Japanese Gardens to see picturesque red bridges over water lily filled ponds. I would love to visit here again in the future with a good book and a picnic basket. The Chinese and Japanese Gardens are truly an underrated natural gem in a bustling metropolis! :)
ADDRESS: 1 Chinese Garden Road Chinese Garden, Singapore 619795, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: Run, don't walk. You may think you've visited arboretums before, but nothing like this. The park itself is well worth a visit with its futuristic tree sculptures which light up at night and the displays in both domes are spectacular, one with many desert plants and the largest baobab trees you'll ever see outside of Africa; but also seasonal floral displays, an ever changing array of colours and scents. We took photo after photo. The second dome features a five storey high cloud forest, a waterfall cascading down from the top and a grillwork catwalk you walk round and round on as if climbing a mountain, amazing displays of orchids, bromeliads, ferns and multi-coloured leafy tropical plants. Who ever said leaves are boring? Give yourself several hours to visit both the domes and gardens. They'll linger in your memory. User friendly
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: The Chinatown heritage centre is in the heart of busy Chinatown, we came across it by accident and decided a visit might be worthwhile. It's a recreation of a shop house of a Chinese tailor and family and workers/apprentices. It has an audio tour, it's informative, interesting and education. Downstairs is a tailors shop with workroom behind and kitchen and outhouse realistically restored. Upstairs is accommodation for workers of other jobs, crammed into small rooms , once again showing how they lived, what they wore and where they slept. Well worth a couple of hours.
ADDRESS: 48 Pagoda Street, Singapore 059207, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: We were in Singapore for a week, and I visited the Buddha Tooth Relic Temple twice. The first visit was a quick 10 minute look while my family went to get some food nearby. It was such a beautiful place that I went back a few days later when I had more time. This is a working Temple, and the prayer and altar areas were roped off, but all other areas are open to visitors. The main level had a small gift kiosk (which supports the Temple), prayer/altar area, and Buddha displays along the sides and beyond the altar. Beautiful reds and golds, resonating with the chanting of the Monks, was stunning. There is a lift that takes you up to a few middle floors housing artefacts that is certainly worth a look. The rooftop garden with a large prayer drum was so tranquil you would not know that you are in the centre of a large city. There are shawls to borrow at the main front entry to cover your shoulders, and shorts are ok, but if they are â€˜short-shortsâ€™ you will be asked by the guard at the front to wrap a shawl around your waist so it covers your thighs. Fantastic experience.

The Gardens themselves are stunning! There are different areas celebrating different things, and the Super Trees are amazing. REVIEW_BODY:
Clean and green. The Singapore Botanic Gardens is a beautiful park free to locals and guests from around the world. If you wish to see the world-class orchids in the Orchid Garden, the entrance fee is a small S$5._x000D_
_x000D_
There are many amazing sculptures to look out for during your walk. I love the one with the marble ball "floating" on water. You can spin the heavy marble ball. It is all about the physics._x000D_
_x000D_
The Gardens has an outdoor amphitheater where you can take in free concerts put on by the Singapore Symphony orchestra._x000D_
_x000D_
There is a diversity of plants and wildlife. I love watching the various waterbirds that take advantage of the ponds in the gardens. There are exotic birds like the hornbills. I also love the adorable squirrels with the handsome black stripes._x000D_
_x000D_
The best time to take in the gardens are the mornings and evenings when it is not too hot and the crepuscular wildlife are out.

REVIEW_BODY: This is one of 2 large Domes in Marina Sands Gardens and as the best of the two ( the other is flowers from different Mediterranean type climate regions). The entrance gives you a 'wow' with a large waterfall falling from roof height cascading through cave like structures and succulant foliage. The tour starts from the lift which takes you up to the 6th floor, you then walk to the 7th to start you walk through the mountain regions. I would advise going on the 1/2 hour and taking in the views from the bottom and then the top. WHY, well on the hour the misting system starts up and after a few minutes gives you the impression of being in a cloud on a hillside - a great effect. There were also numerous sculptures around on our visit and there is plenty of information on climate, plants etching around the walkways. Luckily it is not all steps downwards, elevators take you from floor to floor. However don't miss out the film and timeline sequence at the exit. This is a very sobering experience.

REVIEW_BODY:
Part of the Marina Bay Sands is the curiously shapes Art Science Museum. Its exhibitions are world class and its design is iconic. It is symbolic of the welcoming hand of Singapore with 10 fingers. Natural light filters in through the tip of each finger so the exhibits are seen in the best light. There are 21 galleries spread over three storeys with a total floor space of about 50,000 sq ft._x000D_
As the name suggests, ArtScience Museum at Marina Bay Sands beautifully fuses art and science to tell fascinating stories. This premier venue houses a constantly changing line-up of major international touring exhibitions, brought in through collaborations with organisations such as the American Museum of Natural History, the Smithsonian Institute and world-renowned furniture designer Herman Miller.

REVIEW_TITLE: Our gardens are Singapore's First UNESCO World Heritage site
REVIEW_BODY:
It is one of the most beautiful sites where you can experience flora and fauna of all kinds from all over the globe. We have a Orchid garden within where orchids hold the names of Prime Ministers, Presidents and dignitaries who have come to visit Singapore and been honoured with this custom. Our national flower is the Vanda Miss Joaquim, one species of orchids._x000D_
_x000D_
You can find people, old and young exercising in the garden as early as 5am in the morning. It is a lovely time of the day to just meditate in the midst of all of nature's sights and sounds._x000D_
The Swan Lake is a major attraction in the gardens. It is home to many species of aquatic plants and fishes. We have a Bonsai garden, Sun garden, Healing garden, Rain forest, Ginger garden and so many others._x000D_
_x000D_
Do go there and I guarantee you will not be disappointed. Have a happy adventure.

REVIEW_TITLE: Wonderful attraction. Great for adults and kids.W
REVIEW_BODY:
This is just another example of the way Singapore just gets tourism. This attraction has so much to see that you could spend a whole day there. Firstly, the building itself is architecturally extraordinary, and the gardens are an oasis. Then there is the remarkable ability of Singapore to bring the environment to one of the most densely populated cities in the world._x000D_
_x000D_
We had a great time wandering around the gardens for an hour or so and then paid to go into the Cloud Forest. This was really amazing and even my tired kids loved the displays and the the amazing exhibits. It was well worth the entrance fee._x000D_
_x000D_
After the Cloud Forest the kids were hungry so we headed to Satay By The Bay. This was actually the only slight negative in that it is a longish walk and tucked in the north west corner of the gardens. But I had the best value meal in my whole trip there. Delicious food and where they could very easily have charged high prices, the meals were very reasonably priced._x000D_
_x000D_
The final stop was the water playground and the "treetop" playground for the kids. These were both excellent. The water playground kept them busy for easily an hour and the tree top playground was also excellent. All in all a really fantastic place. Recommend highly.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Fantastic place for the entire family with attractions for the adventurous to the kiddos. I was also surprised that there were enough deck chairs/spaces for everybody._x000D_
_x000D_
Two gripes form me though that I hope the management will take note:_x000D_
1) I fell down at the kiddo area because the tiles were slippery. I was actually quite shocked that it could be that slippery in an obviously wet attraction. Of course it seemed that the management knew about it with all the rubber mats placed around the kiddo play area. Yet these rubber mats proved to be tripping hazards too when it folded up. I tried looking for staff assistance to pull it flat, but unfortunately, none were in sight._x000D_
_x000D_
2) Having towel rentals near the tsunami is a bit of an illogical consequence especially when patrons generally do not carry money with them. At $10 deposit per towel is also ridiculous. I could have made money selling bath towels at half the price at the entrance to the attraction! Hope the management would consider making towel rental easier since it is obviously a need in such a place. To those visiting the place, BRING YOUR TOWELS!
ADDRESS: 1 Pasir Ris Close E!Hub@Downtown East, Singapore 519599, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: Our family booked the Jurong Bird Park Bird's Eye Tour (BET). It was an amazing, memorable and meaningful experience and all of us love it. We were brought around the park in a buggy by our friendly guide. We had up-close, hands-on experience with the various birds (feel, hold and feed hornbill, vultures, brahminy kites, owl and baby bird in breeding center). Our guide and the bird handlers are very friendly and we can feel the enthusiasm and passion that they have in caring for the birds. The birds at the Jurong Bird Park are very well taken care and very beautiful. We highly recommend the Bird's Eye Tour.

REVIEW_BODY:
This is an awesome man-made nature garden in the center of east side of Singapore. Consisting of 2 covered themed domes (flower dome and cloud forest) and a huge open air garden, you can surely spend one day in this recreation park._x000D_
_x000D_
It will be appreciated by everyone in the family, young and old. Even toddlers will enjoy the play areas, including the water park. As it is truly wide, be ready to walk long and enjoy nature in comfy shoes such as sneakers._x000D_
_x000D_
While in the gardens, you will never feel rushed unlike other attractions in Singapore. Just simply enjoy the sights and spend a leisure day here. Strategically located, it is right beside Marina Bay, which you can enjoy at night, after visiting Gardens by the Bay._x000D_
_x000D_
Best thing about the garden for me are the Supertrees, which dominate a certain part of the garden. You can enjoy them both in the afternoon and at night with all the lights on._x000D_
_x000D_
Allocate at least half a day in Gardens by the Bay, in order to truly appreciate its beauty.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Fabulous Flower Dome oasis in the Garden City
REVIEW_BODY:
I have been to the Flower Dome at Gardens by the Bay numerous times as I had an annual pass._x000D_
Now, we brought our overseas guests._x000D_
Currently, they are changing over their exhibits from the Chinese New Year floral displays with pagoda-like structures, so it is not so spectacular._x000D_
But in March there should be new special seasonal floral displays._x000D_
I like this attraction which appeals to both overseas visitors and locals alike._x000D_
During Christmas they have lovely stuffed toy / teddy bear and many festive Seasons displays and props._x000D_
Previous years, they also have beautiful tulip festivals during spring time._x000D_
Repeat visits are also enjoyable since they change their seasonal exhibits regularly._x000D_
I particularly enjoy this large greenhouse attraction since it is a great escape for either inclement rainy or sunny weather._x000D_
But do bring a sweather or light jacket if one is inclined to feel chilly, since the temperature is kept cool at around 23 to 25 degrees celcius._x000D_
This conservatory replicates the cool-dry climate of Mediterranean regions like California, South Africa, South America etc._x000D_
This is a wonderful place for capturing beautiful shots admist myraid of georgeous and colourful flora and plant displays, which can be enjoyed by young and old._x000D_
The best part is that the entry fees are so affordable._x000D_
For overseas guests, it is SGD28 for both conservatories._x000D_
For locals, the senior citizens prices are lower at SGD15 only._x000D_
Check for certain credit card discounts, when purchasing tickets._x000D_
Most definitely not-to-be-missed attraction in Sunny Singapore please.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive Gardens By the Bay, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: A reason for Garden lovers to go to Singapore
REVIEW_BODY:
Gardens by the bay is a destination not just an attraction. It is worth going to Singapore just to go to the gardens. Although the big enclosed domes are the highlight the surrounding, mostly tropical, gardens show the diversity of trees, palms and plants in a magnificent setting._x000D_
The flower dome has a huge array of plants, mostly in flower, from all over the world and is set out in countries and regions. The cloud rain forest dome is a little more specific as most of the plants are from higher altitude, cooler tropical area and has numerous more "indoor" types of plants. A large diverse array of orchards adds much of the colour in there along with gesneriads and other exotica._x000D_
There are flash more expensive places to eat but my preference is the food market area near the children's playground - satay is great._x000D_
If your love plants, plan on seeing this over two days._x000D_
A must see in Singapore.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: A panoramic view of Singapore city
REVIEW_BODY:
The Pinnacle@Duxton is an award-winning 50-storey residential complex near the Chinatown area Singapore. The complex has seven towers which are connected by the world's two longest sky gardens of 500 metres (1,600 ft) each, on both the 26th and 50th floors. The view of Singapore city & the harbour from the 50th floor is panoramic. There is an entry fee of S$6 per person._x000D_
It was great fun taking a long walk and identifying the several landmark buildings & tourist spots of Singapore from the top.

We booked tickets, and it appeared 9:15 pm was the only night option. It is sold "cheap" by a couple of $. We could have gone earlier. Should have had a cold beer or water._x000D_
The dancers were 3 young men. Who twirled fire sticks. They then spent about 20 mins drinking and spraying kerosine, which busty into flame. This is very dramatic, but very unhealthy. Singapore is highly regulated. I am surprised this got past health and safety. I was left breathless from the concentration of kero in the air. I wonder what the "dancers" lung capacity will be like when they turn 30._x000D_
The train ride thru the animals was great. We did not see everyone but quite a lot._x000D_

You will notice a strange sound when traffic lights go green, this apparently has been done to accommodate the blind so they know when to cross the road safely. This city is modern, and everything has been thought of and planned for. You will enjoy Orchard road and the endless shopping. Set a target for the number of malls you want to see, and see if you can achieve your target, it could be fun.

REVIEW_TITLE: Possibly Best Hiking Trail in Singapore
REVIEW_BODY:
Singapore is predominantly an urban city. This is probably the closest thing to a hike that you can get in Singapore. Set aside a minimum of 2 hours for the hike itself. Add more time if you will be stopping anywhere._x000D_
_x000D_
Suggested things to bring: water, poncho or umbrella (in case of sudden rain), ziplock for your precious phone, and of course money (in case you need to buy food/drinks or give up and take train back!)._x000D_
_x000D_
As Singapore weather can get rather hot in the late morning, I would suggest starting at around 7 am. Start from the start point beside the motorbike parking lots, in between Seah Im Food Centre and Marang Road. It's on the east (not west) side of the food centre. You can have breakfast at the food centre before the hike, and wash up at the not-so-clean toilets before the hike. This start point is just next to HarbourFront MRT Station._x000D_
_x000D_
From there, you hike up a series of steps up Mount Faber to the cable car station. This is the Marang Trail. Then you proceed onto the Faber Trail, with panoramic vies of the Southern Part of Singapore. You end up at Henderson Waves, the highest pedestrian bridge in Singapore at 36 metres above Henderson Road._x000D_
_x000D_
Crossing Henderson Waves, you end up in Hilltop Walk, then Forest Walk leading to Alexandra Arch. At this place, you have the option of proceeding westwards towards Flora Walk, HortPark, Canopy Walk and eventually Ken Ridge Park. Or you can turn southwards towards the Labrador Nature & Costal Walk. Normally, at Alexandra Arch, I turn back. Time taken for a normal walk is 1 hour to reach Alexandra Arch and another hour for the return trip. Total distance to Alexandra Arch and back is about 9 km._x000D_
_x000D_
If you are hungry on your return trip, you can get down from Henderson Waves, move northwards towards Telok Blangah Way and locate this place called SAFRA Mount Faber. You can try local coffee (kopi) and toast at Ya Kun. Or you can soldier on and return back to Seah Im Food Centre to try other local food including Indian Rojak._x000D_
_x000D_
Oh I forgot. If you decide to give up at Alexandra Arch, you can navigate southwards to Labrador Park MRT station. Or you can always hail a taxi or Uber from Hort Park!
ADDRESS: Alexandra Road | Mount Faber Park; Telok Blangah Hill Park; or Kent Ridge Park, Singapore 099203, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
To think that the last time we were in Singapore (25 years ago), Gardens by the Bay was no more than part of the sea is incredible, as we gazed in awe at the super trees and walked a little unsteadily along the skyway linking the structures._x000D_
It is probably wise to devote half a day to your visit as we didn't arrive until mid-afterrnoon already exhausted after wandering around the city. Whilst many people take the MRT to the Bayfront station, we opted to walk from Clarke Quay, passing along Boat Quay, the Merlion Park, crossing Jubilee Bridge, around the Marina and across the Helix Bridge._x000D_
Gardens By the Bay is a work in progress and it will be interesting to see how mature the gardens and super trees look in another 25 years._x000D_
Highly recommended.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
The gardens offer a variety of prices, from FREE for the external gardens to $14 each for the two halls. The first is for warmer dryer climes and the second for rain forests. Both halls are amazing, not only are the plants very cool but there are many sculptures interspersed among them. My favourite hall was the rain forest. The amazing high walkways and huge waterfall are spectacular; we did visit as it got dark and so the lighting was well planned and added brilliantly to the scene._x000D_
_x000D_
The light show is 15 minutes long and on twice daily; 7:45pm and 8:45pm. The music is very clear and well choreographed with the lights. If you don't want to spend $30, at least visit for the free gardens and light show, hard to get better value.

REVIEW_BODY: This is a great place to visit for kite-flying, cycling and strolling in an open space. It is the only reservoir located in the city. Suitable for old and young and even those on wheelchair. Fantastic view of the CBD city skyline with Marina BaySands as the backdrop on one side and the sea view with the big ships on the other side. Other highlights include the 350 metres wide bridge that goes to Marina East and an air-conditioned Sustainable Gallery located on the 2nd floor which is also free entry. Booking to the gallery is advised in case of big crowd, which allows entry of 80 pax on hourly basis in the day, except Tuesday. Also available is a small water playground for kids. Within walking distance to the nearest food centre called 'Satay By the Bay'. The inconvenience is that there is only one bus service 400 which is within 5 mintues walk but not so if taking MRT (as the closest isn't ready - still under construction). Also no drinking vending machines or ATMs around, at least not that I could see. But with no entrance fees that needs to be paid, I can't complain much. Parking is available but this isn't free though.
ADDRESS: 8 Marina Gardens Drive Marina Barrage, Singapore 018951, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: One of Singapore's must see's - even if you're not an orchid fan!
REVIEW_BODY: Definitely make time on your itinerary to visit this world-class garden, located within the stunning Botanic Gardens. The $5 entry fee is worth it - there are discounts for seniors, kids etc. Try to visit as early as possible as the heat can get pretty unbearable, but if not make sure to take a hat and plenty of water. There are lovely shaded areas though and some cooled glasshouses with tropical flower displays. Don't miss the unique orchids bred and named for an eclectic mix of politicians and royalty, who have happened to visit Singapore over the years. The Botanic Gardens are well signposted, sprawling and immaculately kept - if you have time do check out other sections, as it really is beautiful.
ADDRESS: 1 Cluny Rd | Within the Singapore Botanic Gardens, Singapore 259569, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
My 7-year old son and I walked up to Fort Canning on a Sunday morning to take the Battlebox tour._x000D_
_x000D_
It started promptly at 9:45 from the visitor centre and was conducted by a very knowledgeable and interesting guide._x000D_
_x000D_
The tour was a mixture of talks and videos on the build up to the Japanese invasion, the tactics they used and the way that the allied forces were forced back into Singapore and finally to capitulation._x000D_
_x000D_
Artefacts and photographs give a real sense of the desperation of the British in the final days of the battle and the eventual end of the war._x000D_
_x000D_
At 7 and interested in history I would say my son was only just ready to take the tour. Older children and certainly only those with an interest in history would be best suited.
ADDRESS: 2 Cox Terrace | Fort Canning Park, Singapore 179622, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
The Cloud Forest was a highlight for my friend and I, we arrived at dusk allowing the plants (growing around and up a seven story artificial mountain) to be viewed in the daylight and later on in the dark. The second of these proving to be the most wonderful, as the plants and cascading waterfall off the mountain side become light up in a vast variety of differing colors. The plants themselves are viewed from a suspended walkway which start on the 7th level (accessed by an elevator) and slowly spirals down and around the mountain. Although very pleasent at first the temperature change from the hot/humid outside to the cool/moist inner climate of the doom did cause us to start feeling cool towards the end of our visit - so I would recommend packing a warm jumper/top to take with you!_x000D_
_x000D_
We didn't book our tickets in advance for this, instead just turned up at the ticket booth at around 18:00 on a Monday. We found that there was no queueing required and that the Cloud Forest was itself nicely empty (allowing the peaceful nature of the place come through)._x000D_
_x000D_

REVIEW_TITLE: I'm not a big fan of Museums, but this one was AWESOME
REVIEW_BODY: I was very lucky to visit exhibition dedicated to the Father of Singapore - Lee Kuan Yew. There were some events held on the first floor: wedding reception in one hall, Leading Ladies of Singapore in the second hall, the History of the MovieMaking in the third hall and the Modern architectural PhotoExhibition in the fourth. The cute cafe was inviting with the smell of the fresh coffee and pastries. I think it's a perfect place for date. On the second floor it was a big exposition about life of an extraordinary pearson, who always worked at himself and never gave up. I LOVEd the museum and the love and RESPECT to life that you see in every detail, HOW people around care about that place. It was May and I noticed a box in the middle of the museum with the envelopes. Everyone could write down the letter to their mothers and the museum would send worldwide the letters for free. I wrote to my mom in Ukraine and she got it in 3 weeks! It was the best museum experience in my life.

REVIEW_BODY:
This is a good activity linking a visit to Bukit Chandu to a visit of Mt Faber. Start in Kent Ridge (recently up-graded), meander along dramatically elevated Alexander Bridge, let your eyes pop out at the beauty & originality of the Henderson Waves, and then wander around Mt Faber: Danish Seamen's Church (where Dr Sun YS stayed), the Merlion on Merlion Point, the Bell of Happiness, etc._x000D_
Tips: 1) Don't bring anything in a plastic bag because the macaques think you have food & will make intimidating faces / gestures at you (they didn't actually threaten me, so don't worry too much! Just be vigilant), 2) Bring your full water bottle. 3) Wear a hat & / or use sun block cream. 4) It's nice and breezy so you don't need bug repellent. 5) Henderson Waves is the real draw card, but it isn't very long; walk the length of the Waves checking out photographic angles, then go back & get your photos... then go back again; just because it's so beautiful & amazing!!!

REVIEW_TITLE: Love the natural scenery, love the fresh air and a meaningful day outing
REVIEW_BODY:
This was not my first time at Bukit Timah Hill. I had once visited here when my children were young, holding their hands up the steep slope. I had also visited here with my childhood friends and remembered our sports shoes were dirtied with mud after an adventurous walking trail filled with mud. This time I am here with my team of grassroots leaders and it was our first time coming back after the nature reserve has renovated._x000D_
_x000D_
Our coach driver seem new to this place and drove us right near the car park of the visitor center and having a hard time maneuvering his way out thereafter. It would be advisable that passengers alight a distance from the car park and walk a short distance to the visitor center if you are coming by bus._x000D_
_x000D_
When we arrived at the visitor center and was taking our photo at the landmark rock at the visitor center, a CISCO guard came and advised me to register at the counter since we are a big group of 33. He explained to me that we should have notified NParks in advance if we are visiting the place as a group. I apologized for my ignorance and wrote down the name of my grassroots organization on the register. So, if you are bringing a full bus load of residents, please notify NParks in advance._x000D_
_x000D_
We decided to do some warm up exercises before proceeding up the hill. One of my members led the warm up exercises. She switched on her hand phone with some music playing to add in fun for the warm up exercises. This time, another CISCO guard approached us after we had finished with our warm-up exercises and told us that music playing is prohibited at the nature reserve. He did not explain the reason just told us it is a rule which we should not violate. Again, I had to apologize for my ignorance._x000D_
_x000D_
Despite these early hiccups, the journey up the hill was exhilarating and refreshing. I sweated profusely as my heart pounded at the most arduous steep slope up to the summit. But it was just a short slope up. It is nothing compared to the multiple long flight of stairs when you are scaling up the mountains in China be it Taishan, Ermeishan or even the Great Wall of China._x000D_
_x000D_
Up at the summit, we took some group photos and commenced our mission impossible: Anti-littering picking and First Aid refresher training. We are a group of First Aiders and we seized this opportunity of outing to revise and refresh our first aid training: refreshing our knowledge on the various bandages for the different types of injuries and wounds and performing the right method of applying CPR. What emergency steps to take if we are being bitten by snakes or accidentally ate a poisonous fruit while doing trekking in a forested area. We had two members who are retired nurses and they were so keen to share their experiences and demonstrate the various first aid techniques. The whole sharing took us about 45 mins and everyone had their hands on._x000D_
_x000D_
After the first aid training, we took our thongs and commenced our anti-littering picking activities with our trash bags. The areas at the summit was perfectly clean except for some little papers here and there. There were many visitors on that weekend but we hardly see much litters along the way. Occasionally, someone dropped some little papers along the way up and we were happily picking them up. The message we are sending to our members is Love our parks and gardens and it is our duty to maintain it clean and green. All of us love nature, love the fresh air, love the green and beautiful scenery and we have to play our part in keeping this country clean at all times._x000D_
_x000D_
We came at about 8 am and completed our two missions and was at the base at about 10 am. We then walked a short distance to Hindhede Quarry and took few beautiful shots at the site._x000D_
_x000D_
As we brisk walked our way to have our meals at Bukit Timah Hawker Center, we were laughing and whistling. It was a great memorable bonding outing and a meaningful day out to perform outdoor learning and keeping our park clean and green. We love the greenery, the f
ADDRESS: 177 Hindhede Drive Bukit Timah Vhf Station, Singapore 589333, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Great fun sneaking around at night!
REVIEW_BODY:
Having spent the day at the zoo and river safari i thought i might be a bit animal-d out by the time of the night safari. How wrong I was! We bought tickets online for 62dollars which gave entrance to the 4 parks (bird park too). We picked the earliest entrance to the night zoo which was 7.15 so that we had the longest time there. I would recommend this as you really do need the time if you want to do and see everything properly._x000D_
The q at the start to get on a tram was long but not unbearable. There's always the option to do the walking tours first and then the tram anyway._x000D_
We did tram first which drove us all round the park and had an informative audio guide. Obviously the animals are not all going to be standing there waiting for us to spot them but that said I think we saw most of them in some way or another._x000D_
After the tram we went to the creatures of the night show. It was a bit of fun but I don't really agree with using animals for performances. After this we saw the fire show. I was expecting a group of people but it was just one man. That said, he was amazing and had us all squirming as he got a bit too close to the flames!_x000D_
After the shows we spent the rest of our night walking round the 4 walking trails and trying to spot all the animals._x000D_
One thing that could be improved, i know the point in that it's a night zoo and should be dark but some enclosures were so dark could see nothing through the windows at all not even a branch! And also some of the lighting was too dim to read the information provided about the animal._x000D_
Great way to end the day, was such a different experience and felt so special being able to wander around at night by ourselves.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
It is definitely an attraction to visit (for first timer) but little has changed over the years, still very much the same old things. After entering the park, most visitors have a choice of 3 main activities, catch the wildlife show, take a tram ride, or go for a trail walk to see the animals. Nothing really wrong about it, just felt jaded. Be prepared to spend 2-3 hours at the place._x000D_
_x000D_
Logistics definitely needs to improve. These include_x000D_
- Shifting the ticket booth closer to the main entrance_x000D_
- Having something to keep the crowd â€˜entertainedâ€™ while waiting in the queue area for the â€œCreatures of the Nightâ€show. Does the crowded really need to stand about in semi darkness too?_x000D_
- Better lighted parkâ€™s trail especially at the edges._x000D_
- Placing some seat along the trail near the animals enclosure for rest break and viewing the display._x000D_
_x000D_
Staff are mostly friendly and helpful. Tram ride was informative and a good way to see the whole park. The whole eco theme being weave into the â€œCreature of the Nightâ€ show was also a nice touch and interesting._x000D_
_x000D_
If you are lucky, you may even catch the feeding of the animals while exploring the trails._x000D_
_x000D_
The park has lots of potential to improve the overall visitorâ€™s experiences and encourage repeat visits just need more attention to details.

As a child I grew up in Singapore and we visited the tiger balm gardens( haw par villa) many, many times._x000D_

It's certainly free now and the best bit is the MRT drops you off right at the gardens._x000D_

No cafe - there is toilets. Go beforehand would be advice and take some drinks._x000D_

REVIEW_TITLE: Worth doing but a slight disappointment
REVIEW_BODY: We were very excited to get to the top of the Marina Bay Sands hotel. We'd seen photographs and read about the infinity pool and although we knew we wouldn't be able to swim in the pool (that privilege is reserved for residents) we were looking forward to seeing it up close. The lift to the top takes you up one side of the hotel and it is almost impossible to get a view of the pool. However, there are still some very impressive views from the top and I'd still recommend doing this. That said I actually thought the Marina Bay Sands hotel was more impressive from the ground. It is a spectacular structure.

REVIEW_TITLE: Simple fun for the young ones...
REVIEW_BODY:
Brought my 10yo daughter there on a Friday afternoon._x000D_
_x000D_
There were very few visitors and it is perfect for us. We took the rides as many times as we like without having to queue for more than 5 minutes._x000D_
_x000D_
The "Torpedo" through which you will experience free fall from 4-storey high is pretty interesting. Another interesting one is the "slide up". The other rides are very common but my daughter still has a lot of fun! She later befriended another young girl and they went off playing by themselves._x000D_
_x000D_
Note:_x000D_
1 Bring slippers as it is difficult to walk on the pebbled-walk way_x000D_
2 Do not bring unnecessary valuables as the locker is pay per use._x000D_
3 There is not much food available for purchase inside the water park, but it is just next to "Downtown East" mall. You are allowed to leave the park for your meal and enter again but ensure you get a stamp on your hand before leaving._x000D_
4 If you are driving, park at the multi-storey carpark of "Downtown East" at walk for 2 minutes to the park.

REVIEW_BODY: Physical churches where established for people of God to worship. I was fortunate to visit the Singaporeâ€™s most famous church. I was awed by the grandeur and elegant facade of the church. The simplicity of the interior made me pray and kneel before God. Thank you was not enough considering that this was my second time to visit Singapore. Singapore made me realized that the world is not only Philippines; that there was a bigger arena for me to explore and wander. My trip to another country would not be complete if I will not visit a church. I felt at peace and guided when I was able to visit a church. Life is too short that one must attached himself to his Creator; that living is not only for oneself but importantly, for the love of mankind especially the needy and less fortunate. Indeed, traveling enabled me to view world in a dynamic perspective and that life is not a solitary thing.

REVIEW_BODY:
We tossed around the idea of going to Sentosa island on the cable cars as we had been to Sentosa Universal Studios & the Aquarium before but had never used the cable cars._x000D_
Lucky we did because it was a bit scary at first but fantastic experience to get a 360 degree view of parts of Singapore, the harbour & Sentosa._x000D_
For the $35 you not only get a ride to the island & back but you also get a ride on the cable car on Sentosa. This too is a great experience as you ride high above the lush green canopy & view parts of the island & outer harbour._x000D_
Have lunch & a stroll around the island & get back on the cable car to take you home._x000D_
Can't recommend it more. Unless you have a mortal fear of heights give it a go. You won't regret it.

REVIEW_BODY:
1. Read about this 10km ridge walk and decided to give it a try. I started from the suggested starting point at Marang trail._x000D_
2. Fairly easy route, and felt it was like a walk in the park, as the route is all paved roads, man made structures and some steps._x000D_
3. There are lots of big beautiful trees along the way but some paths are quite open and hot._x000D_
4. I exited via the entrance to Kent ridge park, and decided to take a bus ride (across the road) to Kent Ridge mrt station as it was getting quite late in the evening._x000D_

REVIEW_BODY:
Right of the bat..I must confess I am not a "zoo" person. The thought of confining animals and stressing them out by hordes of visitors peering at them is not exactly appealing to me._x000D_
_x000D_
But to be fair, the Singapore Zoo makes an effort to give most of the animals space to move around and they try to tell visitors not to bang on the glass and use the flash. Like anywhere in the world, there will be those who will not follow any guidance._x000D_
_x000D_
Having said all of that, it is still a very good place to bring the kids to explore the animal world. It is a bit of a walk especially on a sunny day - so be prepared. You can opt for the tram but you will miss out most of the fun if you just decide to use the tram.

REVIEW_BODY:
The Gardens by the Bay are a definite visit on any trip to Singapore._x000D_
The story behind the Super Trees are amazing and it's a beautiful, serene and incredible space. How it operates and works is phenomenal._x000D_
The suspension bridge walk for just $5 is well worth it and I'd do that over the $18 viewing deck from the tallest super tree._x000D_

The light show in the evening (7.45pm I think) is excellent too.

REVIEW_TITLE: Great, New, Singapore Art Venue and Dining Destination
REVIEW_BODY:
I have been driving by the National Gallery for over a year now. I decided to venture inside and I am definitely glad I did. It is wonderful!_x000D_
_x000D_
First the basics:_x000D_
_x000D_
Yes, they have covered parking which most of the museums in Singapore do not offer._x000D_
_x000D_
Yes, they have discounts available if you're a Singtel Subscriber. Just show them your phone and the Singtel logo to get a discount for the entrance fees._x000D_
_x000D_
Note, that if you want to see everything you will need to pay extra for the various exhibitions that rotate through the National Gallery from quarter to quarter._x000D_
_x000D_
There are restaurants in the Gallery, many of them, are of the sit down, fine dining variety which are only open a few hours at lunch, and again at dinner, so if you're there mid to late afternoon you may go hungry. To check their hours and down load a map to your phone, go to Nationalgallery.sg web site._x000D_
_x000D_
We arrived around 1:30 and meandered through some of the Singapore historical galleries. These galleries contain a wonderfully diverse collection of paintings, etchings, drawings, photographs, sculptures and artifacts from colonial days up through the 60's._x000D_
_x000D_
As we were unaware of the limited dining hours, we managed to get a table at Violet Oons for a late lunch (see separate review)._x000D_
_x000D_
After lunch, we continued to the paid exhibition, entitled "Arist and Empire, (En)Countering Colonial Legacies." This exhibition included a varied collection of works reflecting numerous artists interpretations, from both sides (colonists and colonized) of life during colonial times throughout Asia and India. It was well worth the money paid._x000D_
_x000D_
We also spent some time just checking out the place, admiring the modern additions and updates to these beautiful, old buildings. I especially liked the roof top water garden which creates dancing shadows throughout the interior spaces and beautiful reflecting ponds on the top floor. The top floor offers great views and photo ops of the Padang, where the 7's rugby matches are held, the Esplanade, Marina Bay Sands, and of course, the ever changing Singapore skyline. There is also a restaurant and bar on the top floor, but the weather was too hot to make it a viable option at the end of our day touring the many Galleries below.
ADDRESS: 1 St. Andrew's Road #01-01 National Gallery Singapore, Singapore 178957, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
If there's any park that you want to visit in Singapore, East Coast Park would be among the most highly recommended together with the Botanic Gardens and Gardens by the Bay._x000D_
_x000D_
However, East Coast is distinctively different from the other two Gardens because of its sea-side location. The sand on the beach will never be as soft and smooth as those from other countries, but it has everything else you expect from a beach-side park - picture the warm sea breeze, families on picnic, teenagers on rented bicycles, and the like._x000D_
_x000D_

REVIEW_TITLE: Bike hire, beach and a hive of life
REVIEW_BODY:
East Coast Park is a great way to spend a few hours away from the city centre._x000D_
_x000D_
We got off the circle SMRT line at the Mountbatten station and from there it was around a 20 minute walk down Mountbatten Road to the park_x000D_
_x000D_
We hired two bikes from Bike Stop and from there cycled down the picturesque bike track along the beautiful beach and tanker filled sea. Bike hire was reasonable - we paid 20 dollars each for three hours but shorter, cheaper options were available and the bikes were comfortable and decent even quality._x000D_
_x000D_
Everywhere you looked were people having a great day out - whether cycling, skate boarding, wake boarding, picnicing, playing volleyball, on scooters or just hanging out and taking it easy, it was a great place to spend an afternoon._x000D_
_x000D_
The views of the sea were great, the bike path nice and wide and lots of cafes and shops available for stops along the way._x000D_

A really lovely part of Singapore.

REVIEW_TITLE: The River - the major attractions surrounding are the drawcard
REVIEW_BODY: Singapore River is not one of the great rivers of the world (or even the region) - the point is that it centres the visitor on a variety of attractions, from Clarke Quay and Boat Quay and various river boat attractions (sight seeing/floating restaurants) in one of the most vibrant, essentially man made localities in the world. China Town is near by as is the Singapore Wheel and more eating/restaurant possibilities than any normal traveller could cope with. It is uniquely Singapore - many love it, some are unimpressed but the locality is a must see and do for any visit to Singapore. It will never disappoint.

REVIEW_BODY:
We had bought advance tickets for the Singapore Flyer before leaving the UK to ensure we had the opportunity to take a flight whist in Singapore, but were undecided whether to use them by day or night._x000D_
_x000D_
Having seen the light show in the harbour a night before we decided to see the light show in the Gardens by the Bay and then take a night flight._x000D_
_x000D_
We were not disappointed. Having experienced a number of 'flyers' around the world our experience of this was outstanding. Although we arrived for one of the last flights in the day, there were no queues and our ride was expedited without fuss and well worth the entrance fee._x000D_
_x000D_
There were around a dozen others in the capsule with us all of whom like us wanted to get the best view and take photographs. Everyone was polite and respectful and got what they came for ....... a spectacular view of Singapore by night._x000D_
_x000D_
It was possible to see the World of Palm, Supertree Grove from yet another vantage point together with the incredible Marina Bay Sands development, bay and impressive cityscape._x000D_
_x000D_
Had time permitted we would have taken a daytime flight too._x000D_
_x000D_
If in Singapore take the opportunity of a flight, I can highly recommend it.

REVIEW_BODY:
Quaint little street just off Orchard road (between Centrepoint shopping centre and the tourist office). Itâ€™s flanked on either side by traditional shophouses, many of them prewar. The shophouses at the base of the hill are used for commercial purposes - a few bars that can get quite busy in the evenings and at night. But further up the hill, once youâ€™re past the school on the left, the street becomes very quiet and residential._x000D_
_x000D_
There are some really beautifully restored shophouses along the way, well worth the 5 minute walk up. Where Emerald Hill levels out the houses start getting a bit bigger. There are some sections at the top of the hill which are post-war though (apparently these sections were rebuilt after being damaged during the war) and they donâ€™t have as much charm. Look for the little plaques on the gates of some houses that will give you their history.
ADDRESS: Off Orchard Road, Singapore, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Great place to escape the hot weather
REVIEW_BODY:
Gardens by the Bay is a good starting place for the first time visitor to Singapore. For the locals like us though, it is probably an excellent place to escape the hot and humid climate of Singapore. This is one of the locations in Singapore that was featured in the 2015 movie, Hitman: Agent 47, as well as in the 2015 video game, Call of Duty Black Ops III._x000D_
_x000D_
It is possible to see the Gardens by the Bay free if you are going through the outdoor sections of the area. However the main attractions of the area are the two ticketed indoor conservatories, namely the Flower Dome and the Cloud Forest. For the nature lover, this will be the place for you. You can get to see different varieties of flowers from different continents at the Flower Dome conservatory, while the Cloud Mountain waterfall at the Cloud Forest conservatory should not be missed. Depending of the time you visit, there may be special exhibitions as well, such as during Christmas._x000D_
_x000D_
The best way to reach the Gardens by the Bay currently would be by MRT to Bayfront MRT station and then crossing the bridge to the place through Marina Bay Sands. There is also the taxi option but it is a little more expensive. It is best if possible to try to avoid visiting during public holidays or during the weekends as it can get very crowded and there may be a long wait at the few eating places nearby, other than the Satay by the Bay area which requires at least 5 to 10 minutes walking distance.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Hiking at Bukit Timah Nature Reserve
REVIEW_BODY: Bukit Timah Nature Reserve is one of the connector Parks in the City State in the government ambitious effort to link up all the parks in the whole country. There are several other parks just next to this Nature Reserve, namely Dairy Farm Nature Park, and Hindhede Nature Park. We parked at carpark A near Dairy Farm Nature Park. From here, we walked to Singapore Quarry. Then we backtracked a bit to join to the Rail Corridor (Green Corridor). This former KTMB railway track turned nature trail stretches from Tanjung Pagar Railway Station all the way to Woodland Checkpoint for a total distance of 24km. We trekked a small stretch of it to go to Hindhede Nature Park. We trekked to the Hindhede Quarry before continued to Bukit Timah Nature Reserve. There is a visitor Centre Exhibition at the trail head. We reached the 163.6m Bukit Timah summit using the steeper but shorter Summit Path. This path consists of near to 200 m long staircase. From the summit, we continue to trek to Dairy Farm Loop. It has the steepest climb with long flight of steps. We were trekking in the anti-clockwise direction and it is mainly descending on this Loop to finally join back to the Dairy Farm Nature Park. It will be more demanding if we choose to do a clockwise trekking instead. The whole journey took us a very leisure walk of about 4 hours. We saw a number of land monitor lizards along the way. It is indeed a nice and healthy activities for family during the weekend.
ADDRESS: 177 Hindhede Drive Bukit Timah Vhf Station, Singapore 589333, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Went on school trips as a child and living on the east side, i dont go very often._x000D_
But after 24 years, it brings back fond memories where almost everything looks the same but maintained well._x000D_
Lots of things to see, many halls to discover. My one complaint is the exhibits could have more of a reaction after the kids press the buttons. Some of the buttons pushed had little or even dull activations. Kids want to see things light up to keep their attention. Some didnt work at all. The kid in me was disappointed. I suppose it is a lot of work to do on each exhibit and it takes a lot to engage kids nowadays. Especially the iPad generation._x000D_
But i have nothing to moan about as it was very good value for money where me and my son as locals paid only $6 for me and $4 for him._x000D_
Highlight was that crazy mirror maze, thought itd be easy but was quite a challenge and i got a bit of a panic attack as we went deeper and deeper into it. Had to keep cool for my boy but i was like omg omg omg. We managed to escape. I mean exit. Weirdly, reminded me of my first marriage._x000D_
The science demo show at 4pm was interesting, funny and the hosts entertained my son and the auditorium._x000D_
I love you science centre, i grew up with you in primary school._x000D_
Why cant we have you on the east side.
ADDRESS: 15 Science Centre Road Singapore Science Centre, Singapore 609081, Singapore

Recommended.

REVIEW_BODY:
The Battlebox can only be accessed through a guided tour, which takes 1h15mins and is very frequent through the day. It usually sells out each tour so get to the office about 20 mins early to book your slot._x000D_
_x000D_
Our guide, Diah, was really friendly and very knowledgable during the tour. You are walked through the bunker areas, including strategic rooms and living spaces, and there are also some video presentations about the invasion of Malaya and the defence of Singapore before its invasion. I will say that the tour is quite lenient and sympathetic to the British army officers' situation, and focuses purely on the Japanese invasion and the surrender of the British. Due to the bunker's original purpose, of course the tour does not go into depth about the Japanese occupation of Singapore, or the eventual liberation of the island. This is a good overview of the start of the war in Singapore, and then there are other places to go to learn about the later war years._x000D_
_x000D_
Once you have seen the tour at the Battlebox, you can explore the rest of Fort Canning Hill, as there are paths with information signs around to learn more about the military base situated there.
ADDRESS: 2 Cox Terrace | Fort Canning Park, Singapore 179622, Singapore

Giraffes eating, elephants on show, sea lions and a white lion watching everyone looking at him, and many more! The orangutans were also a definite highlight n the whole experience was made most enjoyable by our tour guide ah meng! We were picked up and dropped off at our hotel. A most enjoyable zoo visit n highly recommend
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: A great day out with the Orangutans for breakfast, and then the rest of the zoo
REVIEW_BODY:
We had breakfast with the Orangutans at the zoo, and then spent up until lunch time exploring the zoo. The breakfast was great, and it is always amazing to see those wonderful creatures close up. It was really well done, with good explanations from the keepers about the program, what they are achieving. Apparently they have a roster for the orangutans, and if they don't want to come out, they don't have to._x000D_
The photo sessions and the queue for close ups with the orangutans was handled well, and in a orderly manner - which you expect in Singapore._x000D_
_x000D_
The rest of the zoo is well laid out, with good sized exhibits. We liked the way the orangutans and other apes/primates had a big run of the place. It was a hot day when we were there (for us anyway), and being able to hop on and off the tram was welcome.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
I read some good reviews about the Battlebox tour on TripAdvisor and decided to sign up for the 1:30 pm slot on a Thursday afternoon. I was not disappointed! Our guide Sharul took us on a tour through several chambers, each furnished the way they could have been during WW2. During each stop, he talked about the events leading up to the Japanese occupation of Singapore. The batch that I toured with was very engaged, and had some good questions for our guide, which he answered throughout the tour. The tour lasts 1 to 1.5 hours depending on the group's pace. SGD 18 allows you to enter a hidden bunker located in Fort Canning Park, through a guided tour. There are several tours at fixed schedules throughout the day, so best to plan your visit around it._x000D_
_x000D_
Other tips:_x000D_
Photography is not allowed inside the bunker._x000D_
I would not recommend this tour for those travelling with young children or babies as they might get restless during the tour._x000D_
The Battlebox visitor center is situated a short walk from the Fort Canning exit of The National Museum of Singapore. You could visit the National Museum for a few hours, exit at its topmost level and walk up to Fort Canning Park in time for one of the afternoon tours. Or you could do the opposite (Battlebox then the National Museum)._x000D_
It is cool inside the bunker, so those who get cold easily should bring a light jacket or cardigan.
ADDRESS: 2 Cox Terrace | Fort Canning Park, Singapore 179622, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Good venue for informal restaurants, bars by the water
REVIEW_BODY:
I was staying at a nearby hotel and strolled down to the Boat Quay to grab a drink, an evening meal and enjoy the views of the river. I've been here a few times before and, on this last occasion, on the last day of the Chinese New Year celebrations, it was nice to see the full moon rising in the distance over the spectacular Marina Bay Sands hotel just visible between the high rise buildings._x000D_
_x000D_
The restaurants here are all very much the same and a few have enthusiastic waiters/waitresses trying to coax you in. There are also a number of busy, noisy bars and the odd establishment with scantily clad young ladies beckoning you in._x000D_
_x000D_
I focused on a nice meal at a table directly on the bank of the river._x000D_
_x000D_
Not bad for a change but it would have been more fun if I'd gone there as a group.

REVIEW_BODY:
The Marina Bay area is an entertainment hub, running around the water front. On it's rim you have the Iconic "Merlion" , The Fullerton hotel, Asian Civilisation museum, downtown skyscrapers, Arts & Science Centre, with Marina Bay Sands hotel and Singapore Flyer standing tall in the background._x000D_
If you are walking from flyer to Marina Bay you pass the Helix bridge. After crossing Helix Bridge you will land in front of Bay Sands Shopping mall. If you are tired just sit near the lotus pond or admire yourself in the spherical Mirrors(see my pics) provided near the Arts & science centre ._x000D_
Added attraction in evenings is the laser show.( warning- on the evening I was there, 10th March 2016, the laser show began half hour late and ended 5 minutes later and no regrets expressed by any one). What little of the show we got to see was nothing to write home about.

REVIEW_TITLE: Great place for a picnic and a walk - also has cafes
REVIEW_BODY: The Botanic gardens are a beautiful place to recover from jet lag. The gardens are free and are easily accessed by bus. There are taxi stands too but I found that the wait was very long. The paths have signs with information about the plants and sometimes history of the site or why the plant is the in garden. There are many pretty fountains, gazebos and sculpture. Be sure to visit the evolution garden with a history of how the earth was formed and the plant life. The gardens have several gift stores and cafe's as well as meeting space and a small museum. There is also a shell for the symphony to perform and many great picnic spots
ADDRESS: 1 Cluny Road, Singapore 259 569, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: Sitting like a jewel box in the Botanical Gardens here in Singapore, for a small admission fee to the National Orchid Gardens (unless you were as lucky as I was during this school vacation period--free for us locals), your eyes get to drink in the colours and quirky good looks of orchids. Smaller ones make you wonder if they are orchids at all as you peer closely at them, and the bigger ones grab you around your ears so to speak, shouting in your face. There are those resembling dainty fairies while others are like heavily bedecked grand dames out to dazzle you. Nestled amongst trees, shrubs and in smart rows all by themselves, these orchids fascinate with their longish creeper like roots anchored on other tree barks, bricks and charcoal in pots, belying their more fastidious natures. Then there are the "VIP ones" named specially after visiting celebrities--more often politicians. They are housed in this charming colonial style bungalow harking to a time long gone. Mostly I marvel at how these living plants have appeared to stop time, not unlike the faded sepia photographs of past generations, while their famous, still living, namesake humans have all gone forward to mark the many years that have elapsed. I strongly recommend you walk among these botanic beauties, resetting your links to nature and reviving your spirit. Go with a loved one, friend, relative, children, visitors...everyone will feel the enchantment.
ADDRESS: 1 Cluny Rd | Within the Singapore Botanic Gardens, Singapore 259569, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
There is so much hype on other reviews about Gardens by the Bay that I came prepared to be disappointed. Far from it - I'm joining the hype. Absolutely wonderful gardens and the two domes are a stroke of genius. I was awestruck by the beauty of the domes and such a wonderful sanctuary to escape the Singapore heat. Both domes are a very pleasant temperature and humidity and it would be easy to stay there all day. Cloud dome is awe-inspiring. A tip for the cloud dome! Essentially you walk along a path and then take a lift to the top and walk along aerial paths and other exhibits on your way back down to where they might expect you to exit. Well that's the psychological idea to keep the crowds moving (and out). Once you are about to exit the dome, if you walk around to the right (and this is not sign posted) you come across the lift that can take you back up to the top. You're actually a level below where you got in!_x000D_
_x000D_
The skywalk is well worth the effort. The entrance to the skywalk is not the easiest to find, even when you might be quite close. Perhaps because it wasn't too crowded there were no queues!!

Whoever conceived of this huge dome clearly had some imagination. Whilst it's possible to see the same trees and plants in other glass houses (think Kew Gardens) this space uses height to convey the phenomenon of different plants that thrive at different levels of the cloud forest. The waterfall and walkways are very impressive and whilst it doesn't take as long to walk through this dome as the flower dome it was worth the price of the double ticket to visit both._x000D_
One exhibit did concern me and that was the collection of huge stalactites and stalagmites which were said to have come from Malaysia. To remove them from their caves, where they take centuries to grow, struck me as vandalism.

REVIEW_TITLE: Possibly the best zoo in the world!
REVIEW_BODY:
This was our second trip to Singapore Zoo and we donâ€™t hesitate to rate it as being the best zoo that we have ever been to (and weâ€™ve been to a few!)._x000D_
The gardens are also so beautifully presented, the amenities are plentiful and immaculate and the entire lay out is superb. The kids zone with extensive water park is an added bonus. If there is one thing that it could improve on, it would be the tram service. We didnâ€™t actually use it, but both times we visited, we noticed that there were massive queues at all the tram stops so this suggests that they need to run more services._x000D_
On both visits we have squeezed in the River Safari (also an outstanding experience) and the zoo on the same day but I think that next time we will definitely devote a whole day to the zoo. Truly exceptional.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Marina Bay Sands Skypark - information in brief
REVIEW_BODY:
Is it worth it? Yes, definitely. Spectacular view!_x000D_
_x000D_
Tickets where to buy: on the internet and at travel agencies, there are only tickets for the next day and later. Tickets for the same day are only available at the hotel. Same price, $ 23 for adults_x000D_
_x000D_
Getting there: Train Station "Bayfront", from there 5 min._x000D_
_x000D_
Ticket office at the hotel: at the end of the hotel in the direction of the sea (Tower 3), at the outside take an escalator to the basement_x000D_
_x000D_
Where is the elevator: at the ticket office_x000D_
_x000D_
What to bring: You do not need jackets, it's windy, but not cold. No suitcases allowed. Backpacks are ok and will not be searched (if you bring "forbidden items", such as drinks, pocket knives)._x000D_
_x000D_
Best time: in the evening it is the most spectacular, especially because of the illuminated water fountains and laser shows and the spectacular skyline. Most busy between 17 and 20 o'clock, long waiting times possible._x000D_
_x000D_
Time required: buy ticket and drive up at least 15 min._x000D_
Stay on top about 30 - 60 minutes. There is no seating._x000D_
_x000D_
Have fun!
ADDRESS: 10 Bayfront Avenue | Level 57, Marina Bay Sands Hotel, Singapore 018956, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
We spent an afternoon in the Flower Dome and Cloud Forest. It was a lovely afternoon (and we got to escape the heat). Afterwards we headed to the children's playground which was worth a stop. Unfortunately we didn't bring swimmers for the kids for the Water Playground but wish that we did. Then had dinner at Satay by the Bay which was really yummy. Really recommend the juice store and in particular the Dragon Fruit and Soursop drink. We got back just in time to see the light show at the Supertree Grove at 7.45pm. We got stuck at the edges as people generally blocked the main steps and passage ways. But there's actually a lot of room right under the "trees" so don't be shy and walk around people to get to the middle. The light show was amazing._x000D_
_x000D_
After the light show there is usually a large pilgrimage of tourists heading back to the MRT. If you can wait - wait a bit. Otherwise, if you head back towards Marina Bay Sands...you can then catch the 9pm laser show there. It's not as good as the Gardens by the Bay show...but might as well since it's so close =)
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
The Asian Civilisations Museum is opposite the Fullerton Hotel. It is a beautiful building which has exhibits on three floors._x000D_
_x000D_
The exhibits tell the story of Asian civilisation through the ages. In one gallery there is a story of a shipwreck. Other galleries have exhibits of jewellery, ceramic and porcelain pottery, art and calligraphy, depictions of various religious beliefs etc. All the exhibits are beautiful and are well documented._x000D_
_x000D_
The museum is a place of cultural education. I would recommend that you take a guided tour. There are many additional bits of information that the guide will give you._x000D_
_x000D_
At the end of your tour, you will welcome a visit to the cafe which sells a selection of hot and cold drinks and snacks. I would recommend a visit to the souvenir shop too._x000D_
_x000D_
The museum is open daily from 10am to 7pm - but on Fridays it closes at 9pm. Admission is free to Singapore citizens and permanent residents. Adult foreign visitors have to pay SGD8 - but if visiting on a Friday between 7pm and 9pm - the price is SGD4.
ADDRESS: 1 Empress Place Empress Place Building, Singapore 179555, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: An amazing overview of Singapore's history.
REVIEW_BODY:
I've travelled to Singapore many times but only visited the National Museum on my last trip - I'm glad I made the time and would recommend it to tourists or business travellers who have never bothered._x000D_
_x000D_
Set in a beautiful building and grounds, the exhibits cover the history of the region going back several hundred years, Singapore's role in World War 2 and culminate with the story of Singapore's journey to independence, it's cultural development and how it became the economic powerhouse of SE Asia._x000D_
_x000D_
There is a small entrance fee for foreign nationals but it is definitely worth spending the money.
ADDRESS: 93 Stamford Road National Museum of Singapore, Singapore 178897, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
The December School holidays gave us a fair bit of time to visit different attractions._x000D_
_x000D_
The arrival of the Christmas Wonderland gave us a good excuse to visit the Supertree grove and we went over a couple of times._x000D_
_x000D_
The parking lot was fairly full both times owing to the holidays._x000D_
_x000D_
The Christmas Wonderland had a few interesting rides and games for kids but the draw was clearly the super trees._x000D_
_x000D_
Entry to the walkway is very well managed and is restricted to a few visitors. The tickets are sold by slots and run out very quickly. Entry is also closed during inclement weather._x000D_
_x000D_
An elevator takes you to the walkway and the view of Singapore as well as the rest of the Gardens By The Bay is simply superb. We went at dusk time and were fortunate enough to not just see the light up (beautiful) but due to the presence of the Christmas Wonderland, we were able to see the lighting in sync with music from Frozen._x000D_

Well worth the effort and wait.

REVIEW_BODY:
I always thought a zoo is a lame idea for a weekend getaway.._x000D_
but then again, I was just a snotty little kid when I last visited a wildlife attraction that barely got me interested._x000D_
Fate brought me to the Singapore Zoo and immediately thought the place was amazing. They have a pair of the rare white tigers, collection of birds, mammals that even include a polar bear, other big cats, and playful elephants (that you can ride for a fee). You can get up close to giant reptiles that are at the top of their food chain, and more assortment of rainforest eco-community surrounded by just mere (sometimes inexistent) fences._x000D_
Really an exhilarating experience._x000D_
The place is huge & closes by afternoon (for the night safari), so my advice is, get there early to have a more complete tour of this animal kingdom that you just mostly see on the Animal Planet, Discovery Ch. or Nat Geo._x000D_
It'll also give you the opportunity to watch and even participate with the feeding segments. If you happen to visit during summer and unfortunately suffer cramps from a lot of walking, you can take the tram, or the boat to get to places within the park._x000D_
The food is nice, but like most parks, they're quite pricey._x000D_
Bring your own bottle of ice cold water.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY:
Everyone I talked to mentioned that I NEEDED to go to the Gardens by the Bay if I ever go to Singapore. I thought that people were just in the same bandwagon and wanted me to hop on in, little did I know that their persistent recommendations of the attraction were not at all exaggerations. I was only able to visit a certain part of the overall place because of time restraints, but it definitely left a BIG impression on me._x000D_
_x000D_
Obviously, the highlights of the attraction were the numerous plants/flowers and the impressive horticulture that was done to them. Never in my wildest dreams could I have ever imagined that a place like this could exist; I've lived in a concrete jungle all my life and I rarely got the chance to be around swaths of plant life._x000D_
_x000D_
It's a shame that I only got to see a certain portion (plus one dome, darn 2 hour line for the Cloud Forest...), but I definitely plan to go back here when I do go back to Singapore one day.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore
