REVIEW_BODY:
St Andrew's Cathedral, once a prominent landmark in central Singapore City, is now dwarfed by the surrounding skyscrapers of Singapore's financial district._x000D_
_x000D_
But its all-white exterior catches your attention as you drive or walk past on St Andrews Road._x000D_
_x000D_
The original St Andrew's Church was built in 1835 and the second was built in 1842._x000D_
_x000D_
It was demolished in 1855 after two lightening strikes and rumours of evil spirits and devils spiting the church._x000D_
_x000D_
The new foundation stone was laid in 1856 and the first service was in 1861._x000D_
_x000D_
Today St Andrew's Cathedral is the focal point of the Anglican community in Singapore._x000D_
_x000D_
It is open to the public, and even if you are not a Christian, it is worth visiting, sitting in a pew, and quietly contemplating how peaceful it is inside compared the the hustle and bustle of outside modern Singapore City.
ADDRESS: 11 St. Andrew's Road St. Andrew's Cathedral, Singapore 178959, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Could have spend whole night here
REVIEW_BODY:
Gardens by the by is a place to be. If you are in Singapore, you cannot actually miss these wonderful creations. Go there after 6 in the evening, enjoy cloud forest and then come out to see the light and sound show which has specific timings._x000D_
You have to take the battery operated buses to reach this place which costs around 3SGD as far as I remember._x000D_
There is also something where you can go to the tops of those lit trees and enjoy the sound and light show but I found it better from a distance. REVIEW_BODY:
Singapore Zoo is an open concept zoo ._x000D_
The animals seem well cared for and have enough pen space given according to their size and needs. Though I felt at some of the places the water was very dirty and that bothered me that the animals did not have a clean poolof water to wade in to._x000D_
There are the Tram rides which take you aroubd the Zoo and you get to spot places where you want to come back and visit for a longer period. There are hundreds of animals to see , feeding sessions, A Splash Safari show and the Rainforest Kidsworld. You can also walk on a ropeway. There are specialised Educational tours, Guided tours, have Breakfast with the Orangutans etc and its a educational fun day for young & old. There are also restaurants for you to recuperate, refresh and get back on the trail to see the animals and the animal shows._x000D_
Highly recommended._x000D_
_x000D_
Also would suggest get the four parks tickets incl the tram rides for the Singapore Zoo, Jurong Bird Park, NightcSafariband River safari on the Wildlife Reserves website and it gives a great price much more economical then getting individual tickets. This ticket is valid for seven days so is a great saving. And no ticketing queues just go to the entrances and the staff let you in after checking your tickets.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Green peace in a hectic city
REVIEW_BODY:
The Singapore Botanic Gardens are a haven of calm in this hectic city. Don't confuse them with the Gardens by the Bay, which is a modern confection for undiscerning visitors._x000D_
If all you want is a gentle walk through interesting trees and shrubs, this is for you. If you are a serious student of tropical botany, you will find nowhere better to study the results of nearly 200 years of endeavour. Take your camera, and take your time - allow at least half a day. The best place to start is at the main entrance, although taxi drivers will want to drop you off at one of the other gates, as it will be then easier for them to pick up another fare._x000D_
Start by looking at the specialist sections to the east of the entrance, and wander round the large lake._x000D_
If you have not seen it before, pay the small extra to see the orchid garden._x000D_
We then recommend you to meander slowly down to the Tanglin Road gate, not forgetting the interesting modern sculptures._x000D_
Don't forget to take a bottle of water.
ADDRESS: 1 Cluny Road, Singapore 259 569, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Absolutely wonderful zoo... Great accessible enclosures
REVIEW_BODY:
We really loved the zoo... Caught a taxi there from China town for around $15 Aussie dollars. We looked at what time feeding times were for the giraffes and elephants and I really wanted to do that and made sure we were there for those... Feeding costs five dollars and you can take as many photos as you want... They have a professional photographer there but we didn't even look at their photos._x000D_
_x000D_
The enclosures are all really good for viewing the animals from different view points. It was a hot day but there is a shuttle bus team thing you can pay five dollars for and get on and off at different stops... We didn't use it and managed ok but did a fair amount of sweating. The food and drinks in the zoo are adequately elevated but we thought this was OK as profits went to animal keep. The Australian are was closed for renovations.... That's ok we've seen all them anyway lol._x000D_
_x000D_
You can do the zoo in just over two hours ... So go spend a morning there and enjoy a beautifully forests and kept garden and zoo aNd healthy animals.

REVIEW_BODY: If you're in Singapore , you must include one of these two in your itinerary. Singapore flyer or the boat cruise at Merlion Park. The latter is reviewed in detail ( check out my reviews ). The flyer is a giant wheel ride of approximately 30 minutes. It rotates ever so slowly that you can have a good look at Singapore's waterline ( the dock/bay area ) and also the beautiful city itself. While you're in the ride, you'll find the water below quite pleasing to the eye. One coupe can roughly house 16-18 people at once though the seating arrangement is not enough for all but the ride itself is enjoyable. You can get the tickets arranged on the spot or have your travel agent do it for you .Have fun !
ADDRESS: 30 Raffles Avenue, Singapore 039803, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Beautiful park and so thankful that we live walking distance from it

We go every week with our friends, mums and kids, all enjoy having a picnic, near the duck pond @ the Cluny End, where its a large open space (so we can watch them playing frisbee/football).

First time to visit. We booked 20:15 one and got there around 19:45, however, the waiting line for the tram was already super long, and it took us 45 mins to start the tour._x000D_
The worst part is that we couldn't attend the Creatures of the Night Show._x000D_
Our tram tour finished just before 21:30, and we rush to the show, but the staff said the show is full and we couldn't attend._x000D_
This is VERY unprofessional._x000D_
A woman, who also couldn't attend the show, was claiming that why they sell so many ticket and many people cannot enjoy the show even though the ticket price is same._x000D_
That is so true._x000D_
We paid same price, and some could enjoy the show and some couldn't._x000D_
21:30 is the last show of the weekday._x000D_
_x000D_
I went there with my guest who came over from Japan and she was VERY disappointed. Me too._x000D_
This is what they should announce more clearly._x000D_
If you want to enjoy the show, go there by 19:00, and enjoy show from 19:30, then get on the tram tour from 20:15, and enjoy walking trail till the safari is closed._x000D_
This is only the way you can enjoy all of the safari. I hope you don't waste money._x000D_

REVIEW_BODY:
I have to admit that my expectations of Singapore zoo were quite high as most reviews of the zoo are very complimentary._x000D_
This zoo is very beautiful as it is surrounded by rainforest gardens which are beautifully maintained. Some of the exhibits are quite clever such as the free ranging orangutan exhibit that is above one of the main walkway intersections. I also thought the ethiopian monkey exhibit was quite good although some of the monkeys looked liked they required medical attention. Most of the exhibits were very small and I personally felt that most needed to be at least 4 times the size. We also checked out the elephant show, that supposedly showed the "bond between mahoot and elephant." All I saw were men with hooks on sticks ( the hooks were disguised by having ribbon tied on them), exerting their will on the elephants. For a zoo that preaches the 5 freedoms of animals, having a show where the keepers hook the animals by the skin or behind the ear to get them to perform tricks for people, seems quite contradictory._x000D_
This zoo also educates the public about the destruction of rainforests which is good but as most of the snacks in the zoo contain palm oil, it's another case of do as I say not not as I do. I think this zoo needs to focus on the message it's sending and lead by example instead of taking the easy path and pretending to be unaware of what is being sold or what behaviour is happening within its park._x000D_
We took our 6 year old and the highlight of her visit was the waterpark. It's a great idea and a welcome respite after a hot day walking around the zoo. The flooring is very tired and needs replacing though as it has large pieces missing from it. I also liked the child pulling wagons and thought they were a great idea.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: Even though Singapore is expensive, the array of products available is unbeatable. Orchard Road has the best variety of shops ranging from good old and well-known H&M and Zara to less prominent stores like Harry Winston, Cartier, Prada and Valentino and the best of couture. I love shopping due to the variety and products available for different price groups. Prefer ION as compared to the rest. Paragon is also great. There are a couple of hotels and service apartments on and off Orchard Road. There are also numerous places to eat, snack, grab a coffee or even a beer. Love the bustling energy, enthusiastic shoppers and tourists. If nothing else, walk on the streets and do some people watching.

REVIEW_TITLE: Singapore Zoo, River Safari and Night Safari - all in one day!
REVIEW_BODY:
Yep, we did all those 3 parks in 1 day - first week of October._x000D_
_x000D_
We took Uber and arrived around 11.30am and bought tickets at the counter (you could get them online too). We bought the 4 in 1 package which include: Singapore Zoo, River Safari, Night Safari and Jurong Bird Park._x000D_
_x000D_
The ticket lady booked us on to the 7.15pm for Night Safari, the earliest one (they had several time slots at night)._x000D_
_x000D_
We were here for about 4 hours and managed to cover everything. It's a big park but easy to follow with map or hopped on the tram. Lots to see. One of the best zoo in the world! Lots of indoor areas to cool down if too hot outside._x000D_
_x000D_
Food prices were around SGD$10 onwards, no SGD$2.80 nasi lemak here ha ha!_x000D_
_x000D_
We managed to cover all 3; Singapore Zoo, River Safari and Night Safari from 11.30am - 10pm! What a day, worth every cent.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Beautiful area to while away an afternoon
REVIEW_BODY: Gardens by the Bay is a must see for anybody coming to Singapore. You can choose to spend some time walking around the grounds or pay to go into the Flower Dome and Cloud Forest (there is a reduced rate for buying both tickets together). I would recommend going to see these at least once. The flower dome changes its major attractions seasonally so it will depend when you go as to what you will see but there are always things to see for old, young and in between. The super tree grove lights up every evening at 7.45 and 8.45. This show is ace and all the trees light up to various popular tracks. If you get there early you can queue to go on the skywalk for $5 at the time that the lights are on giving you a different view of the show. It really is amazing that Singapore puts on these types of events every evening for free. A must see!!

REVIEW_TITLE: Great place to spend a late afternoon
REVIEW_BODY:
Our Experience: we reached here a little later than expected around 6 or 6.30 pm.. so could not visit the entire garden.. and before we could start it started pouring cats and dogs.. so we wore our ponchos and rushed to the light show.. it was absolutely stunning.._x000D_
_x000D_
TIPS:_x000D_
1. Make sure u reach here at around 3 or 4 pm to truly enjoy every aspect of it._x000D_
2. The light show at 7.45 and 8.45 is a must watch so dont miss it._x000D_
3. Carry ur ponchos or raincoats even if the weather app tells u its not going to rain._x000D_
4. There are 3 aspects to the Gardens by the Bay. First is the paid conservatories, Second the free gardens around the conservatories and Third is the light show._x000D_
So if u dont have enough time and want to rush through it u can just visit the free Gardens and i must tell u they are gorgeous._x000D_
The light show is also free but has specified timings so dont miss that show._x000D_
If it rains and ur looking for a good spot to watch the light show here are the directions. When u cross the Dragonfly Bridge walk past the Malay Gardens and just before u reach the Chinese gardens there is a washroom on ur right. u must take the right turn that comes just before the turn to the washroom and as u walk there u will find a nice sheltered place to watch the show.

REVIEW_TITLE: Worth a visit but needs more wow!
REVIEW_BODY:
We were at River Safari, Singapore on the 27'th of March, Pleasant trip with 4adults and 3 kids with one being a toddler. Surprisingly comfortable and not too sweltering in todays humidity with many fans and a/c areas around the park. Some portions of the park is also shaded and some has cooling areas :) Nice setup unfortunately the displays should have more matured fishes, ie. a small wallago and goonch when it could be a monster fish? Nice planted setup with many schooling fishes too, beautiful colors but most (70-80%) of fishes can be found in petshops around Singapore and Malaysia. With their setups was expecting to see more matured tanks ie. a full cichlid community from tanganyika. Or being able to see a fully grown Bagarius! Sorry, being a fish aficionado was expecting a "WOW", Place has potentially, hopefully it'd survive till then :)_x000D_

REVIEW_TITLE: Nice, large City Park across from Clarke Quay
REVIEW_BODY:
Sitting on the grounds of the former Fort Canning, and prior ancient temples, this a great spot to go for a stroll or run. It's accessible via metro, bus and/or walking. It's a fairly large park and you can enter from many different areas, and it gets popular on weekends. There's history to be seen here with the old fort walls/bastions/cannons, and some houses/structures. There's also an art museum near the top of the hill you can tour. A few cafes are located on the grounds (one inside the art museum, and some along the outskirts). There's also a hotel on the grounds. Lots of green here, very pleasant for walking. Strollers and wheelchairs can also be used. It's great for a jog and there are some pull-up bars, balance beams, etc. along the path for further exercise. The national museum can be accessed after coming out of the Northeast side of the park._x000D_
_x000D_
For a tour, word is it's a stop on the World War II tour out of the Changi Museum.
ADDRESS: River Valley Rd, Singapore 179038, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Lovely walks through woodland to the skywalk through the treetops
REVIEW_BODY:
There is a large area of woodland around the MacRitchie reservoir, with many paths. We only walked from the main car park to the Skywalk (about 45 mins walk for fit adults, not stopping to take many pictures, longer with children or keen photographers!), over the Skywalk and then back round via the Tower. The paths through the woods are great, there are lots of monkeys, best to watch them while keeping walking, if you stand still too long they start to come a bit too close! Great to see them jumping across the walkway. The bridge through the tree tops is great, with terrific views. Note you can only go one direction across it, so have to come back via a circular route. There are lots of other paths that we didn't take, but may some other time._x000D_
To get there, we took the bus 410 from Bishan interchange. There is 410G and 410W which basically go opposite ways round a loop. I think it is approx at the far point of the loop, so probably doesn't matter too much which you get. Ask the driver for Upper Thompson Rd (same price to all stops on that road, so you don't need to say more than that). We took the 410G and stayed on till nearly the end of Upper Thomson Rd, we got off by the petrol station. If you stay on longer than that, the bus turns right at the crossroads, where the MacRitchie is to the left. The shop at the petrol station sells drinks, crisps, cakes, so you can get a minimal picnic from it (the lady serving was very friendly). We caught the 410W back from the other side of the road. The buses go pretty regularly (every 15 mins or so, I think?)_x000D_
We got a few insect bites, so some repellent might be useful, also sun cream even though you under the trees a lot of the time, and definitely some drinking water.
ADDRESS: MacRitchie Reservoir Park, Singapore 298717, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: with its own, Singaporean perspective - and contrary to some reviews here, I find it exceptionally well-curated. The displays are also aesthetically thought through without being self-important (as in the MAK in Vienna, say); I think it compares well with the East and Southeast Asian divisions in the V&A in London and - if smaller - with the Guimet in Paris. It is not comprehensive, nor meant to be, but many of the pieces are of very high quality, such as Chinese porcelain and the excellent (if biased) display on Imperial Chinese scholar-poet-bureaucrats. The shop is disappointing. Altogether a nice, very pleasant experience.
ADDRESS: 1 Empress Place Empress Place Building, Singapore 179555, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: What a wonderful garden area, free!
REVIEW_BODY: If you choose to go to a pavilion there is a fee. We did go on the walk through the fake tree tops. Every thing is about the environment and sustainability. We paid S$8 each for 15 minutes to walk from one side of the solar trees to the other. There are creatures created in shrubs, there are open spaces, eating options and a new exhibit called Once Upon A Time Tomorrow. Basically what famous locations might look like after people. It is extraordinary. Especially liking those places I've been. It is not pessimistic but rather hopeful. We spent several hours going through the different parts of the gardens, even including petrified wood from Indonesia. Then there's the baby... Well worth the trip and time to view and enjoy yet another excellent spot in Singapore.

REVIEW_TITLE: An oasis of beauty and calm in the middle of a bustling city state
REVIEW_BODY: This garden looks big on the map and is even larger in person, running nearly 2 Km from north to south. We chose to take the MRT to the Botanic Garden station at the north end, and walk south through the garden. Admission is free, which surprised us. There are many sub areas in the park, so you are unlikely to see them all in a single visit. Like everything else in Singapore, the entire park is spotless and impeccably maintained. The pathways integrate beautifully with the landscape, and many are lit for night use. Signage in the park is very well done, so one can quickly study the signs at each path intersection, and decide which way to go to see individual areas. All paths lead to the Orchid Gardens in the southern third of the park. We exited the south end of the park and walked to the Orchard Road MRT station, stopping to shop along the way, for the trip back to our hotel. I can see how this park is popular with visitors and locals alike.
ADDRESS: 1 Cluny Road, Singapore 259 569, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Great Insight to the Role of Changi Prison during the Japanese Occupation
REVIEW_BODY:
The Changi Museum is located a few miles west of Changi village. To get there, take the East West MRT line to Tanah Merah station and then bus number 2 to the museum._x000D_
_x000D_
Although there is an audio guide, there is plenty of information to read to last several hours. There was some interesting art produced by some of the inmates, and the murals in the chapel by Stanley Warren were very touching._x000D_
_x000D_
Coupled with the Battlebox and the displays at the Ford Motor Factory, a very comprehensive view of Singapore before, during and after the Second World War is portrayed._x000D_
_x000D_
Admission is free and refreshments are available on site.
ADDRESS: 1000 Upper Changi Road North, Singapore 507707, Singapore

REVIEW_BODY: If you have just come off a long flight and have a bit of jet-lag, this is the perfect place to spend an initial half-day or so in Singapore. It is totally delightful for all ages (without taxing the brain like a museum). We also visited the Cloud Forest and Flower Dome and later on wandered through the Supertree Grove on our route back to the Marina Bay area. We lingered as it was by then after 7pm and we saw the Grove come to life with a fantastic light show and accompanying music. It is an amazing visual spectacle (photo buffs will be very enthused) but it also feels so rewarding to just be there! We went back to see the Supertree Grove light-show on another day before heading out to dinner. There is a good vantage point on the walkway and bridge from the Marina Bay Sands. We paid to get into the domes but otherwise we took a taxi to get there and just wandered around (no tour involved). I would like to rate this a six or seven, much more than a five!

REVIEW_TITLE: Green haven in middle of city
REVIEW_BODY: City in a garden or garden city or city of gardens - call it whatever but one thing is sure that it is a remarkable piece of artistry and creation of green space in middle of a bustling metropolis. It will calm and relax your senses and get you back on perspective. Garden by the bay consists of three distinct areas - east , central and south. All three are phenomenal though I am a little biased towards south as it overlooks the iconic Marina bay sands and has outstanding conservatories like flower dome and lost forest plus the super tree grove. Not many countries can boast of such outstanding initiatives. Crowded on weekends and be prepared for lines and hence online booking is a better option. Tickets are slightly expensive. 33 sgd for adult on s weekend plus 20 for a kid but worth every penny

REVIEW_BODY:
Spent several hours wandering round Chinatown, exploring the colourful goods, clothes, souvenirs, interesting buildings including temples. However the most impressive were the various hawkers offerings of food. The Maxwell food court was clearly the place to try to Singapore chicken rice judging by the long queues, but there are other interesting food areas selling a wide range of dishes and drinks throughout Chinatown. The ones we tried were incredible value for money, understandably it is packed at lunchtimes. Make sure you donâ€™t sit at a table if there is a pack of tissues on it, as that it how people reserve the table whilst they queue at the various stalls. (We learnt this the hard way!)_x000D_
We also enjoyed watching the preparations for the Chinese New Year, with dozens of pigs (fortunately plastic!) being wired up as illuminated decorations. Just a pity we arenâ€™t there for the actual festivities in February.

REVIEW_TITLE: Like the Maldives on a roof!
REVIEW_BODY:
Beautiful place. If you are a hotel guest access is free. There is a nightclub terrace bar on Tower 3 and a large Italian bar and grill on top of tower 1 in between them there is a giant infinity pool. There are loads of seats and beds in a variety of options, there are jacuzzi pools and observation seats. The pool is huge and split into family zone and adults only. There is an abundance of staff bringing drinks and food to you. In the main concourse area there is a large bar and diner by Wolfgang Puck and you can sit and dine in the main area or the bar anytime._x000D_
Above all (excuse the pun!)_x000D_
To swim to the waters edge and look down 55 stores to the marina below is an experience not to missed. H a cocktail in hand and look down on the forest and gardens behind the hotel is just wonderful._x000D_
As with everywhere you go in this hotel, the staff are great. Lots of friendly people more than happy to go the extra mile to make you happy and comfortable_x000D_

REVIEW_BODY:

_x000D_
Started our walk at the 'visitor centre' and walked the whole park in about 3.5 hours. Ended up at the 'wetlands centre' where the security guard was happy to call us a local cab, which arrived after 10 mins._x000D_
_x000D_
Saw everything, without having to make much effort. Blue kingfishers, estuarine crocodiles, huge monitor lizards, many colourful exotic birds, a family of resident monkeys (make sure no food is on display), jumping fish, turtles, huge spiders, mudskippers, fascinating fish, sea eagle, nice views of Malaysia across the water._x000D_
_x000D_
Best day out to be had in Singapore. No crowds and a real glimpse into the real Singapore._x000D_
_x000D_
Note: take own food and drinks - there are only a couple of vending machines. There are two sets of clean, comfortable toilets on site.

REVIEW_BODY:
- One of the entrances is located just next to Bayfront MRT station, so the Gardens are easy to access. If you're feeling lazy, you can even purchase a ticket for a shuttle vehicle that will take you right to the conservatories (but you'll miss the joy of exploring the Gardens on your way)._x000D_
- If you're looking for a good spot to watch the light & sound show in the evening, after leaving the station follow the signs leading to the main parts of the Garden until you see a lake on your right. Stop there and appreciate the show._x000D_
- Prepare yourself for the trip according to the weather conditions. Personally, I preferred to visit the Gardens when it was cloudy. On a dry and sunny day I wasn't even able to reach the Gardens' entrance - it was too hot and the stroll wouldn't have been enjoyable at all._x000D_
(However, if you decide to choose the "bad" weather same as I did, mind that most likely you won't be able to enter the OCBC Skywalk - it's closed whenever there's a risk of rain or strong wind)._x000D_
- Put on some warm clothes before you enter the conservatories - it's quite cold inside, especially in the Cloud Forest._x000D_
- If you want to return to the MRT station, trust your memory and intuition more than the direction signs. I've noticed that some of them don't point the shortest / easiest way back.
ADDRESS: 18 Marina Gardens Drive | Bayfront Plaza, Singapore 018953, Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Good visit with senior citizens and infant
REVIEW_BODY:
We (2 adults, 2 senior citizens and 1 infant) visited the zoo on a Saturday. Since the zoo is not easily accessible by MRT (required multiple hops from Tanah Merah, where I live) we chose to go by taxi. The taxi dropped us right at the main entrance (about 8:25 AM) - very convenient._x000D_
_x000D_
We entered the zoo and were handed maps by the eager staff. The map was quite informative, and we chose to walk in the direction suggested by the map. We visited the otters through the rain forest walk, followed by the primates section. The enclosures of the animals seemed to be well maintained and we were able to see the animals right away._x000D_
_x000D_
We then proceeded to Ah Meng restaurant for a breakfast with the orangutans. We had to pay a steep price of S$35 per person for an entry. Also, infant strollers/prams were not allowed and had to be kept outside. The buffet menu itself had quite the variety, both veg and non-veg items, and multiple cuisines. As we managed to reach the restaurant by 8:30, we were able to enjoy breakfast in peace. The orangutans came to their pre designated place at 9:30 and after a brief introduction everyone had to line up for a photo with them. A good option would be to reach early, have breakfast and be ready by the time orangutans come. That way you won't have to leave your breakfast in between. We had to wait a short while in the line for taking pictures with the orangutans. The photographers did let you take pictures with your mobiles, so it was not mandatory to buy the professional pictures._x000D_
_x000D_
There's a small area out this restaurant that has a play area for children. This was well appreciated, as we could let our (wiggling) daughter down for some free stretches._x000D_
_x000D_
Following the great outing with the orangutans, we proceeded to the 'splash safari' show. It was quite a well rehearsed and applaud worthy performance and was enjoyed by one and all. The show was in a covered stepped auditorium with the sea lions performing at the bottom. Front row people may get wet with the sea lions splashing water._x000D_
_x000D_
Once the show was done, our planned itinerary was sppoiled a bit by unprecedented heavy rains. Luckily there was a covered pathway near the splash safari show (not all places have covered pathways). We had to wait in the covered pathway for about 45 min, and then proceded to other areas of the zoo._x000D_
_x000D_
For lunch, we had packed and taken our lunch with us. We had lunch in 'Pavillion by the lake' in the Australian Zone. The lunch area is a big open covered space (with few ceiling fans not working). Plastic chairs have been provided for sitting, but it was not very convenient to sit with your lunch box in your hand. The area was clean, however. Enough to let our daughter crawl on the floor._x000D_
_x000D_
The zoo is well equipped with diaper changing stations, and benches to sit (particularly for the elderly). There aren't many places where you could let a 12 month infant (crawling age) down for a stretch. The zoo also provides a tram facility, however we preffered to walk. The tram would have been useful during a drizzle (not particularly useful during heavy rains, as it is open). Be aware that a lot of walking is required around the zoo and hence carrying some rehydrating liquids would be recommended._x000D_
_x000D_
Once we came out of the zoo (about 4 PM), we faced a slight inconvenience of transportation back home. Expect a minimum waiting time of 20 min at the taxi stand. Not all taxis will come to the area that you want to go. So your wait in the queue might be extended. Albeit, the zoo runs a free shuttle to the nearest MRT station, from where you can possibly take multiple MRTs elsewhere. With senior citizens and an infant, this option was not particularly sought after by us. But I wanted to make a note that the zoo had made some provisions. After a reasonably long wait in the taxi queue, we managed to get one and started our journey back home, tired but satisfied with what the zoo had to offer.
ADDRESS: 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, Singapore
